title: Teaching People LLM's Errors and Getting it Right
summary:
People use large language models (LLMs) when they should not. This is partly because they see LLMs compose poems and answer intricate questions, so they understandably, but incorrectly, assume LLMs won't stumble on basic tasks like simple arithmetic. Prior work has tried to address this by clustering instance embeddings into regions where an LLM is likely to fail and automatically describing patterns in these regions. The found failure patterns are taught to users to mitigate their overreliance. Yet, this approach has not fully succeeded. In this analysis paper, we aim to understand why.
  We first examine whether the negative result stems from the absence of failure patterns. We group instances in two datasets by their meta-labels and evaluate an LLM's predictions on these groups. We then define criteria to flag groups that are sizable and where the LLM is error-prone, and find meta-label groups that meet these criteria. Their meta-labels are the LLM's failure patterns that could be taught to users, so they do exist. We next test whether prompting and embedding-based approaches can surface these known failures. Without this, users cannot be taught about them to reduce their overreliance. We find mixed results across methods, which could explain the negative result. Finally, we revisit the final metric that measures teaching effectiveness. We propose to assess a user's ability to effectively use the given failure patterns to anticipate when an LLM is error-prone. A user study shows a positive effect from teaching with this metric, unlike the human-AI team accuracy. Our findings show that teaching failure patterns could be a viable approach to mitigating overreliance, but success depends on better automated failure-discovery methods and using metrics like ours.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes why prior attempts at teaching users LLM failure patterns did not sufficiently reduce overreliance and shows that such teaching can work if failures are better discovered and more appropriate evaluation metrics are used.
AI.motivation: Users often overtrust LLMs even on tasks where these models are unreliable, partly because impressive capabilities on complex tasks make them seem competent on simple ones. Prior work tried to reduce overreliance by discovering and explaining patterns of model failures, but reported limited success. This paper is motivated by the need to understand why those approaches underperformed and whether the concept of teaching failure patterns is fundamentally flawed or just implemented imperfectly.
AI.method: 1) Empirically group instances from two datasets by meta-labels that describe interpretable properties of the inputs. 2) For each group, evaluate an LLM’s performance and define criteria (group size and high error rate) to flag groups where the LLM is consistently error-prone; treat the associated meta-labels as ground-truth failure patterns. 3) Test whether existing prompting-based and embedding-based automatic discovery methods can recover these known failure patterns, analyzing where they succeed or fail. 4) Re-examine how the effect of teaching failure patterns is measured and introduce a new metric focused on users’ ability to anticipate LLM errors. 5) Run a user study comparing teaching conditions using this new metric and traditional human-AI team accuracy.
AI.result: The authors show that (a) meaningful, interpretable failure patterns do exist: certain meta-label-defined groups are both sizable and systematically error-prone for the LLM; (b) current automated methods for discovering such patterns via prompting and embeddings only partially surface these known failures, with mixed performance that likely explains earlier negative results; and (c) when teaching is evaluated with a metric that directly measures users’ ability to anticipate LLM errors, a positive teaching effect is observed, in contrast to the lack of improvement seen when using human-AI team accuracy alone.
AI.conclusion: Teaching users about LLM failure patterns is not inherently ineffective; prior negative results are partly due to limitations in automatic failure-pattern discovery and in the choice of evaluation metric. With reliable methods to identify failure-prone regions of the input space and with metrics that capture users’ improved error anticipation, teaching failure patterns emerges as a promising strategy to mitigate overreliance on LLMs.

title: Morality is Contextual: Learning Interpretable Moral Contexts from Human Data with Probabilistic Clustering and Large Language Models
summary: Moral actions are judged not only by their outcomes but by the context in which they occur. We present COMETH (Contextual Organization of Moral Evaluation from Textual Human inputs), a framework that integrates a probabilistic context learner with LLM-based semantic abstraction and human moral evaluations to model how context shapes the acceptability of ambiguous actions. We curate an empirically grounded dataset of 300 scenarios across six core actions (violating Do not kill, Do not deceive, and Do not break the law) and collect ternary judgments (Blame/Neutral/Support) from N=101 participants. A preprocessing pipeline standardizes actions via an LLM filter and MiniLM embeddings with K-means, producing robust, reproducible core-action clusters. COMETH then learns action-specific moral contexts by clustering scenarios online from human judgment distributions using principled divergence criteria. To generalize and explain predictions, a Generalization module extracts concise, non-evaluative binary contextual features and learns feature weights in a transparent likelihood-based model. Empirically, COMETH roughly doubles alignment with majority human judgments relative to end-to-end LLM prompting (approx. 60% vs. approx. 30% on average), while revealing which contextual features drive its predictions. The contributions are: (i) an empirically grounded moral-context dataset, (ii) a reproducible pipeline combining human judgments with model-based context learning and LLM semantics, and (iii) an interpretable alternative to end-to-end LLMs for context-sensitive moral prediction and explanation.

AI.tldr: Introduces COMETH, a framework that models how context shapes moral judgments of ambiguous actions, outperforming direct LLM prompting while remaining interpretable.
AI.motivation: Moral evaluation of actions depends heavily on contextual details, but current LLM-based approaches to moral prediction often ignore or inadequately represent context and are usually opaque. There is a need for an empirically grounded, interpretable system that can learn how specific contextual factors influence human moral judgments, rather than relying on black-box end-to-end LLM prompts.
AI.method: They build COMETH, combining: (1) a curated dataset of 300 scenarios spanning six core morally relevant action types (e.g., killing, deception, law-breaking) with ternary human judgments (Blame/Neutral/Support) from 101 participants; (2) an LLM-based and MiniLM+K-means preprocessing pipeline that standardizes and clusters core actions; (3) a probabilistic context learner that clusters scenarios online within each action type based on distributions of human judgments, using divergence-based criteria; and (4) a Generalization module that extracts concise, binary, non-evaluative contextual features and fits a transparent likelihood-based model that learns weights for these features to predict judgments and explain which contextual elements matter.
AI.result: COMETH achieves about 60% alignment with majority human moral judgments, roughly double the performance of direct end-to-end LLM prompting at around 30%. The model also produces interpretable feature weights that indicate which contextual factors drive its moral predictions, and yields stable, reproducible clusters of core actions and contexts.
AI.conclusion: Context can be systematically learned and represented to improve moral prediction over naive LLM prompting, and doing so in a structured, probabilistic, and feature-based way yields both better empirical alignment with human judgments and interpretable explanations. The work provides (i) a new moral-context dataset, (ii) a reproducible pipeline that couples human data with automated context learning and semantic abstraction, and (iii) an interpretable, context-sensitive alternative to black-box LLMs for modeling moral evaluation.

title: Oogiri-Master: Benchmarking Humor Understanding via Oogiri
summary: Humor is a salient testbed for human-like creative thinking in large language models (LLMs). We study humor using the Japanese creative response game Oogiri, in which participants produce witty responses to a given prompt, and ask the following research question: What makes such responses funny to humans? Previous work has offered only limited reliable means to answer this question. Existing datasets contain few candidate responses per prompt, expose popularity signals during ratings, and lack objective and comparable metrics for funniness. Thus, we introduce Oogiri-Master and Oogiri-Corpus, which are a benchmark and dataset designed to enable rigorous evaluation of humor understanding in LLMs. Each prompt is paired with approximately 100 diverse candidate responses, and funniness is rated independently by approximately 100 human judges without access to others' ratings, reducing popularity bias and enabling robust aggregation. Using Oogiri-Corpus, we conduct a quantitative analysis of the linguistic factors associated with funniness, such as text length, ambiguity, and incongruity resolution, and derive objective metrics for predicting human judgments. Subsequently, we benchmark a range of LLMs and human baselines in Oogiri-Master, demonstrating that state-of-the-art models approach human performance and that insight-augmented prompting improves the model performance. Our results provide a principled basis for evaluating and advancing humor understanding in LLMs.

AI.tldr: They build a large-scale Japanese humor dataset and benchmark to rigorously evaluate and analyze humor understanding in LLMs.
AI.motivation: Existing humor datasets are too limited to robustly study what makes textual jokes funny and to evaluate LLM humor; they have few responses per prompt, popularity bias in ratings, and lack objective funniness metrics.
AI.method: They create two resources: Oogiri-Corpus, a dataset of Japanese Oogiri prompts each with ~100 diverse responses and ~100 independent funniness ratings per response; and Oogiri-Master, a benchmark task. They quantitatively analyze linguistic features (length, ambiguity, incongruity resolution) that correlate with funniness and derive predictive metrics. They then test various LLMs and human baselines on the benchmark, including insight-augmented prompting strategies.
AI.result: They identify linguistic factors and objective metrics that predict human funniness judgments, and find that strong LLMs can come close to human performance on the Oogiri humor task, with improved scores when given helpful insights in prompts.
AI.conclusion: A carefully designed Oogiri-based dataset and benchmark makes humor in text empirically measurable; this enables principled evaluation of LLM humor understanding, shows that current models nearly match humans under some settings, and highlights that prompting strategies can further enhance machine humor performance.

title: Beyond Heuristics: A Decision-Theoretic Framework for Agent Memory Management
summary: External memory is a key component of modern large language model (LLM) systems, enabling long-term interaction and personalization. Despite its importance, memory management is still largely driven by hand-designed heuristics, offering little insight into the long-term and uncertain consequences of memory decisions. In practice, choices about what to read or write shape future retrieval and downstream behavior in ways that are difficult to anticipate. We argue that memory management should be viewed as a sequential decision-making problem under uncertainty, where the utility of memory is delayed and dependent on future interactions. To this end, we propose DAM (Decision-theoretic Agent Memory), a decision-theoretic framework that decomposes memory management into immediate information access and hierarchical storage maintenance. Within this architecture, candidate operations are evaluated via value functions and uncertainty estimators, enabling an aggregate policy to arbitrate decisions based on estimated long-term utility and risk. Our contribution is not a new algorithm, but a principled reframing that clarifies the limitations of heuristic approaches and provides a foundation for future research on uncertainty-aware memory systems.

AI.tldr: The paper reframes external memory management in LLM systems as a sequential decision-making problem under uncertainty, proposing a decision-theoretic framework (DAM) that uses value functions and uncertainty estimates to guide read/write operations for long-term utility.
AI.motivation: External memory is vital for long-term interaction and personalization in LLM systems, but current memory management relies on ad hoc heuristics that ignore long-term, uncertain effects of memory decisions. The authors aim to provide a principled way to reason about which memories to read, write, and retain, considering delayed utility and future interactions.
AI.method: They introduce DAM (Decision-theoretic Agent Memory), an architectural and conceptual framework that decomposes memory management into two subproblems: immediate information access and hierarchical storage maintenance. Within this framework, each candidate memory operation is scored with value functions and uncertainty estimators, and an aggregate policy arbitrates among them based on estimated long-term utility and risk, framing memory operations as sequential decisions under uncertainty rather than static heuristics.
AI.result: The work does not claim a novel algorithmic result, but instead offers a formal decision-theoretic framing of LLM memory management. It shows how value-based and uncertainty-aware evaluation of memory operations can replace heuristic rules, and clarifies where existing approaches fall short in handling long-term and uncertain consequences of memory decisions.
AI.conclusion: Memory management for LLMs should be treated as a sequential decision-making problem with delayed and uncertain rewards. The DAM framework provides a principled way to decompose and evaluate memory operations using value and uncertainty estimates, highlighting the limitations of heuristic approaches and establishing a foundation for future research on uncertainty-aware external memory systems.

title: From Visual Perception to Deep Empathy: An Automated Assessment Framework for House-Tree-Person Drawings Using Multimodal LLMs and Multi-Agent Collaboration
summary:
Background: The House-Tree-Person (HTP) drawing test, introduced by John Buck in 1948, remains a widely used projective technique in clinical psychology. However, it has long faced challenges such as heterogeneous scoring standards, reliance on examiners subjective experience, and a lack of a unified quantitative coding system.
  Results: Quantitative experiments showed that the mean semantic similarity between Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) interpretations and human expert interpretations was approximately 0.75 (standard deviation about 0.05). In structurally oriented expert data sets, this similarity rose to 0.85, indicating expert-level baseline comprehension. Qualitative analyses demonstrated that the multi-agent system, by integrating social-psychological perspectives and destigmatizing narratives, effectively corrected visual hallucinations and produced psychological reports with high ecological validity and internal coherence.
  Conclusions: The findings confirm the potential of multimodal large models as standardized tools for projective assessment. The proposed multi-agent framework, by dividing roles, decouples feature recognition from psychological inference and offers a new paradigm for digital mental-health services.
  Keywords: House-Tree-Person test; multimodal large language model; multi-agent collaboration; cosine similarity; computational psychology; artificial intelligence

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates a multimodal large language model (MLLM) and a multi-agent framework as a standardized, quantitative interpretation system for the House-Tree-Person (HTP) projective drawing test, showing high semantic similarity with human experts and improved interpretive coherence.
AI.motivation: The HTP test is widely used but suffers from subjective, heterogeneous scoring and lacks a unified quantitative coding system, limiting its reliability, standardization, and scalability. The authors aim to explore whether MLLMs can provide consistent, expert-level, and more objective interpretations of HTP drawings, and thus modernize projective assessment for digital mental-health services.
AI.method: The authors use a multimodal large language model capable of processing both images (HTP drawings) and text, embedded in a multi-agent system where different agents take distinct roles (e.g., visual feature recognition, psychological inference, social-psychological contextualization). They compare MLLM-generated interpretations with expert-written interpretations using semantic similarity (cosine similarity) metrics, analyzing both quantitatively (mean similarity scores) and qualitatively (ecological validity, internal coherence, correction of hallucinations).
AI.result: Quantitative experiments show that MLLM interpretations achieve a mean semantic similarity of about 0.75 (SD≈0.05) with human expert interpretations, increasing to about 0.85 in structurally oriented expert datasets, which is close to expert-level comprehension. Qualitatively, the multi-agent system integrates social-psychological perspectives and destigmatizing narratives, reduces visual hallucinations, and produces psychologically plausible, coherent reports.
AI.conclusion: Multimodal large language models, especially when organized in a multi-agent framework that separates feature recognition from psychological inference, can serve as standardized, scalable tools for projective assessment like the HTP test. This offers a new, more objective and ecologically valid paradigm for digital mental-health services, potentially addressing long-standing issues of subjectivity and lack of standardization in projective techniques.

title: A Unified Definition of Hallucination, Or: It's the World Model, Stupid
summary:
Despite numerous attempts to solve the issue of hallucination since the inception of neural language models, it remains a problem in even frontier large language models today. Why is this the case? We walk through definitions of hallucination used in the literature from a historical perspective up to the current day, and fold them into a single definition of hallucination, wherein different prior definitions focus on different aspects of our definition. At its core, we argue that hallucination is simply inaccurate (internal) world modeling, in a form where it is observable to the user (e.g., stating a fact which contradicts a knowledge base, or producing a summary which contradicts a known source). By varying the reference world model as well as the knowledge conflict policy (e.g., knowledge base vs. in-context), we arrive at the different existing definitions of hallucination present in the literature.
  We argue that this unified view is useful because it forces evaluations to make clear their assumed "world" or source of truth, clarifies what should and should not be called hallucination (as opposed to planning or reward/incentive-related errors), and provides a common language to compare benchmarks and mitigation techniques. Building on this definition, we outline plans for a family of benchmarks in which hallucinations are defined as mismatches with synthetic but fully specified world models in different environments, and sketch out how these benchmarks can use such settings to stress-test and improve the world modeling components of language models.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a unified, world-model-based definition of hallucination in language models and uses it to guide evaluation benchmarks and mitigation strategies.
AI.motivation: Hallucinations in neural and large language models persist despite many mitigation attempts, partly because the term is inconsistently defined across the literature. This lack of a shared conceptual framework makes it hard to compare results, design robust evaluations, or understand what is actually being fixed. The authors aim to resolve this by providing a single, coherent definition that subsumes prior ones and clarifies what counts as hallucination versus other error types.
AI.method: The authors conduct a conceptual and historical analysis of how hallucination has been defined in prior work. They abstract these definitions into a unified framework where hallucination is framed as inaccurate internal world modeling made externally observable. Key dimensions are the choice of reference world model (e.g., knowledge base, source document, environment) and the policy for conflict resolution among knowledge sources (e.g., KB vs. in-context information). They then use this framework to propose a design for new benchmarks built on synthetic, fully specified world models.
AI.result: They obtain a single, unified definition of hallucination that generalizes many previous definitions as special cases, depending on the reference world and conflict policy. Using this definition, they distinguish hallucinations from other failures such as planning mistakes or reward-driven behavior that does not reflect mis-modeled world knowledge. They also outline a benchmark family in which hallucinations are precisely defined as mismatches between a model’s outputs and a fully known synthetic world, allowing systematic stress-testing of world modeling capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Hallucination in language models is best understood as inaccurate internal world modeling that becomes visible in the model’s outputs relative to a specified source of truth. Making the assumed world model and conflict policy explicit clarifies evaluation, improves comparability of benchmarks and mitigation methods, and avoids conflating hallucinations with other error modes. Synthetic, fully specified worlds offer a principled way to build benchmarks that directly probe and enhance the world modeling components of language models.

title: A Study of Solving Life-and-Death Problems in Go Using Relevance-Zone Based Solvers
comment: Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Games
summary: This paper analyzes the behavior of solving Life-and-Death (L&D) problems in the game of Go using current state-of-the-art computer Go solvers with two techniques: the Relevance-Zone Based Search (RZS) and the relevance-zone pattern table. We examined the solutions derived by relevance-zone based solvers on seven L&D problems from the renowned book "Life and Death Dictionary" written by Cho Chikun, a Go grandmaster, and found several interesting results. First, for each problem, the solvers identify a relevance-zone that highlights the critical areas for solving. Second, the solvers discover a series of patterns, including some that are rare. Finally, the solvers even find different answers compared to the given solutions for two problems. We also identified two issues with the solver: (a) it misjudges values of rare patterns, and (b) it tends to prioritize living directly rather than maximizing territory, which differs from the behavior of human Go players. We suggest possible approaches to address these issues in future work. Our code and data are available at https://rlg.iis.sinica.edu.tw/papers/study-LD-RZ.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how state-of-the-art Go solvers use relevance-zone based search to solve life-and-death problems, identifying strengths and weaknesses versus human play.
AI.motivation: Life-and-Death (L&D) problems in Go are critical for strength and require precise reading and pattern recognition. Modern computer Go solvers can solve them, but their internal reasoning and differences from human intuition are not well understood. The authors want to open this black box: to see what regions the solvers consider important, what patterns they discover, and how their decisions compare to classical expert solutions from a standard reference book.
AI.method: They apply relevance-zone based search (RZS) and a relevance-zone pattern table to seven L&D problems from Cho Chikun’s well-known "Life and Death Dictionary." For each problem, they run state-of-the-art L&D solvers that use RZS, extract the computed relevance-zones, and log the patterns the solvers rely on. They then compare the solver’s solutions and inferred patterns against the original book’s solutions and human expectations, analyzing discrepancies and failure modes (e.g., misvalued rare patterns, preference for immediate life vs. territory maximization).
AI.result: For every tested problem, the RZS solvers identify a clear relevance-zone that correctly highlights the critical local area needed for solving the L&D situation. The solvers also uncover multiple local patterns, including some rare patterns not commonly emphasized in human study. In two of the seven problems, the solvers find correct but different solutions compared to those given in the book. However, they also show systematic issues: misjudgment of the values of rare patterns and a bias toward moves that secure life directly rather than those that optimize territorial gain in ways that human experts often prefer.
AI.conclusion: Relevance-zone based Go solvers can effectively focus on critical regions and discover meaningful patterns in Life-and-Death problems, even producing alternative valid solutions to expert-published answers. Nonetheless, they have notable limitations in valuing rare patterns and aligning with human strategic preferences regarding territory. The authors propose that future work refine pattern valuation and incorporate objectives or learning schemes that better balance survival and territorial considerations, and they release their code and data to support further research.

title: Gamayun's Path to Multilingual Mastery: Cost-Efficient Training of a 1.5B-Parameter LLM
summary: We present Gamayun, a 1.5B-parameter multilingual language model trained entirely from scratch on 2.5T tokens. Designed for efficiency and deployment in resource-constrained environments, Gamayun addresses the lack of research on small non-English-centric LLMs by adopting a novel two-stage pre-training strategy: balanced multilingual training for cross-lingual alignment, followed by high-quality English enrichment to transfer performance gains across languages. Our model supports 12 languages, with special focus on Russian. Despite a significantly smaller training budget than comparable models, Gamayun outperforms LLaMA3.2-1B (9T tokens) on all considered benchmarks, and surpasses Qwen2.5-1.5B (18T tokens) on a wide range of English and multilingual tasks. It matches or exceeds Qwen3 (36T tokens) on most tasks outside advanced STEM, achieving state-of-the-art results in Russian, including the MERA benchmark, among the models of comparable size (1-2B parameters).

AI.tldr: Gamayun is a 1.5B-parameter multilingual LLM trained from scratch with a two-stage pretraining strategy that achieves state-of-the-art performance in Russian and strong multilingual results despite a much smaller training budget than competitors.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of small, efficient, non-English-centric language models suitable for deployment in resource-constrained environments, and existing multilingual models often require large parameter counts and training budgets. The authors want a compact model that still offers strong performance across several languages, with emphasis on Russian.
AI.method: The authors build a 1.5B-parameter model, Gamayun, and train it from scratch on 2.5T tokens using a novel two-stage pre-training scheme: (1) balanced multilingual training across 12 languages to achieve strong cross-lingual alignment, and (2) high-quality English enrichment to further boost capabilities in English and transfer these improvements to other languages. They then evaluate Gamayun on a suite of English and multilingual benchmarks, with special focus on Russian tasks.
AI.result: Gamayun, with only 2.5T training tokens, outperforms LLaMA3.2-1B trained on 9T tokens on all reported benchmarks, and surpasses Qwen2.5-1.5B trained on 18T tokens on many English and multilingual tasks. It also matches or exceeds Qwen3 trained on 36T tokens on most tasks except advanced STEM, and sets new state-of-the-art results in Russian (e.g., MERA) among 1–2B-parameter models.
AI.conclusion: A carefully designed two-stage pretraining process can make a small, from-scratch, 1.5B-parameter multilingual model highly competitive with much more expensively trained baselines, particularly for Russian and other supported languages, making it suitable for efficient deployment in resource-limited settings.

title: Three-way conflict analysis based on alliance and conflict functions
summary: Trisecting agents, issues, and agent pairs are essential topics of three-way conflict analysis. They have been commonly studied based on either a rating or an auxiliary function. A rating function defines the positive, negative, or neutral ratings of agents on issues. An auxiliary function defines the alliance, conflict, and neutrality relations between agents. These functions measure two opposite aspects in a single function, leading to challenges in interpreting their aggregations over a group of issues or agents. For example, when studying agent relations regarding a set of issues, a standard aggregation takes the average of an auxiliary function concerning single issues. Therefore, a pair of alliance +1 and conflict -1 relations will produce the same result as a pair of neutrality 0 relations, although the attitudes represented by the two pairs are very different. To clarify semantics, we separate the two opposite aspects in an auxiliary function into a pair of alliance and conflict functions. Accordingly, we trisect the agents, issues, and agent pairs and investigate their applications in solving a few crucial questions in conflict analysis. Particularly, we explore the concepts of alliance sets and strategies. A real-world application is given to illustrate the proposed models.

AI.tldr: The paper refines three-way conflict analysis by separating alliance and conflict into two distinct functions, avoiding semantic ambiguity in aggregated measures and enabling clearer modeling of alliance sets and strategies, demonstrated via a real-world case.
AI.motivation: Existing three-way conflict analysis uses single rating or auxiliary functions that simultaneously encode opposite aspects (e.g., alliance vs. conflict or positive vs. negative) in one value. When aggregating across multiple issues or agents, this causes interpretive problems—such as averaging +1 (alliance) and -1 (conflict) to 0, which is indistinguishable from two neutral 0 relations despite representing very different underlying attitudes. The authors aim to remove this ambiguity and provide more semantically faithful tools for analyzing multi-agent, multi-issue conflicts and alliances.
AI.method: The authors conceptually and formally separate the two opposite aspects of the auxiliary function (alliance and conflict) into two independent functions: an alliance function and a conflict function. Using these, they define three-way (trisected) structures for agents, issues, and agent pairs, classifying them into three categories based on degrees of alliance, conflict, and neutrality. They then develop derived notions such as alliance sets and strategies, and propose procedures for using the new dual-function framework to analyze conflicts over sets of issues and groups of agents. A real-world case study is used to instantiate and validate the modeling approach.
AI.result: The new framework demonstrates that keeping alliance and conflict in separate functions preserves important semantic differences that are lost under traditional single-function averaging. The trisected categorizations of agents, issues, and agent pairs lead to more nuanced identification of alliances, conflicts, and neutralities in multi-issue settings. The case study shows that the model can better distinguish between genuinely neutral relations and relations that average to neutrality due to mixed strong alliance and strong conflict stances across issues, and it yields more interpretable alliance sets and strategies.
AI.conclusion: Separating alliance and conflict into two functions and trisecting agents, issues, and agent pairs improves the semantic clarity and analytical power of three-way conflict analysis. The approach avoids misleading aggregations, supports more accurate identification of alliances and conflicts over multiple issues, and facilitates the design and evaluation of alliance sets and strategies. The real-world application indicates the framework’s practical usefulness, suggesting it can be applied to broader conflict analysis and decision-support scenarios.

title: Feasible strategies in three-way conflict analysis with three-valued ratings
summary: Most existing work on three-way conflict analysis has focused on trisecting agent pairs, agents, or issues, which contributes to understanding the nature of conflicts but falls short in addressing their resolution. Specifically, the formulation of feasible strategies, as an essential component of conflict resolution and mitigation, has received insufficient scholarly attention. Therefore, this paper aims to investigate feasible strategies from two perspectives of consistency and non-consistency. Particularly, we begin with computing the overall rating of a clique of agents based on positive and negative similarity degrees. Afterwards, considering the weights of both agents and issues, we propose weighted consistency and non-consistency measures, which are respectively used to identify the feasible strategies for a clique of agents. Algorithms are developed to identify feasible strategies, $L$-order feasible strategies, and the corresponding optimal ones. Finally, to demonstrate the practicality, effectiveness, and superiority of the proposed models, we apply them to two commonly used case studies on NBA labor negotiations and development plans for Gansu Province and conduct a sensitivity analysis on parameters and a comparative analysis with existing state-of-the-art conflict analysis approaches. The comparison results demonstrate that our conflict resolution models outperform the conventional approaches by unifying weighted agent-issue evaluation with consistency and non-consistency measures to enable the systematic identification of not only feasible strategies but also optimal solutions.

AI.tldr: The paper extends three-way conflict analysis from descriptive trisecting toward prescriptive conflict resolution by defining and computing feasible and optimal strategies for groups of agents using weighted consistency and non-consistency measures, validated on real negotiation and planning cases.
AI.motivation: Existing three-way conflict analysis methods primarily classify or trisect agents, agent pairs, or issues to understand conflict structures but do not directly support designing and selecting strategies to resolve or mitigate conflicts. In particular, formulating practically feasible strategies that reconcile multiple agents’ preferences across multiple issues, while accounting for both agreements and disagreements and different importance weights, has been underexplored. The authors want to fill this gap by introducing a quantitative framework that turns three-way analysis into a strategy-recommendation tool.
AI.method: The authors work in a three-way conflict analysis setting and focus on cliques of agents. They first define how to compute an overall rating for a clique based on positive and negative similarity degrees of agents’ stances on issues. Then, incorporating weights for both agents and issues, they construct weighted consistency and non-consistency measures. These measures are used to determine which strategies are feasible for a clique. They develop algorithms to (1) enumerate feasible strategies, (2) generate L-order feasible strategies (strategies that satisfy constraints at a certain threshold or rank level), and (3) select corresponding optimal strategies based on the defined measures. The models and algorithms are implemented and applied to two benchmark conflict scenarios: NBA labor negotiations and development planning for Gansu Province. Sensitivity analysis is conducted on parameters, and comparative experiments are performed against existing conflict analysis methods.
AI.result: The proposed models and algorithms successfully identify feasible and L-order feasible strategies, as well as optimal strategies, for the studied conflict cases. In the NBA labor negotiation and Gansu development planning examples, the framework yields strategy sets that meet the weighted consistency and non-consistency criteria and highlight trade-offs among agents and issues. Sensitivity analysis shows the models are robust to parameter changes, and comparative analysis indicates better performance than state-of-the-art approaches in terms of systematically incorporating agent and issue weights and leveraging three-way measures. The outcomes demonstrate that combining positive/negative similarity with weighted consistency measures leads to more nuanced and actionable conflict-resolution recommendations.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that extending three-way conflict analysis with weighted consistency and non-consistency measures enables a shift from mere conflict diagnosis to strategy-oriented conflict resolution. By integrating agent and issue weights with similarity-based ratings for cliques, the proposed framework can systematically derive feasible and optimal strategies. The empirical studies on NBA labor negotiations and Gansu development planning show improved effectiveness and practicality compared with conventional methods. The authors argue that their approach provides a more comprehensive and unified methodology for conflict resolution and that it can be adapted to other multi-agent, multi-issue conflict scenarios.

title: Heaven-Sent or Hell-Bent? Benchmarking the Intelligence and Defectiveness of LLM Hallucinations
comment: Published as a conference paper at KDD 2026
summary: Hallucinations in large language models (LLMs) are commonly regarded as errors to be minimized. However, recent perspectives suggest that some hallucinations may encode creative or epistemically valuable content, a dimension that remains underquantified in current literature. Existing hallucination detection methods primarily focus on factual consistency, struggling to handle heterogeneous scientific tasks and balance creativity with accuracy. To address these challenges, we propose HIC-Bench, a novel evaluation framework that categorizes hallucinations into Intelligent Hallucinations (IH) and Defective Hallucinations (DH), enabling systematic investigation of their interplay in LLM creativity. HIC-Bench features three core characteristics: (1) Structured IH/DH Assessment. using a multi-dimensional metric matrix integrating Torrance Tests of Creative Thinking (TTCT) metrics (Originality, Feasibility, Value) with hallucination-specific dimensions (scientific plausibility, factual deviation); (2) Cross-Domain Applicability. spanning ten scientific domains with open-ended innovation tasks; and (3) Dynamic Prompt Optimization. leveraging the Dynamic Hallucination Prompt (DHP) to guide models toward creative and reliable outputs. The evaluation process employs multiple LLM judges, averaging scores to mitigate bias, with human annotators verifying IH/DH classifications. Experimental results reveal a nonlinear relationship between IH and DH, demonstrating that creativity and correctness can be jointly optimized. These insights position IH as a catalyst for creativity and reveal the ability of LLM hallucinations to drive scientific innovation.Additionally, the HIC-Bench offers a valuable platform for advancing research into the creative intelligence of LLM hallucinations.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces HIC-Bench, a benchmark to distinguish and quantify ‘intelligent’ vs ‘defective’ hallucinations in LLMs and to study how hallucinations can contribute to creativity while maintaining correctness.
AI.motivation: Current work treats hallucinations in LLMs purely as errors, focusing on factual consistency. But some hallucinations may contain creative or epistemically valuable ideas, especially in scientific contexts. Existing detectors don’t quantify this creative value, don’t generalize well across diverse scientific domains, and don’t help balance creativity with reliability. The authors want a systematic way to measure and harness ‘good’ hallucinations instead of just suppressing them.
AI.method: They build HIC-Bench, an evaluation framework that: (1) categorizes hallucinations into Intelligent Hallucinations (IH, potentially creative and valuable) and Defective Hallucinations (DH, misleading or low-value) using a multi-dimensional metric matrix combining Torrance Tests of Creative Thinking dimensions (Originality, Feasibility, Value) with hallucination-specific axes (scientific plausibility, factual deviation); (2) covers ten scientific domains with open-ended innovation tasks to test cross-domain creativity; and (3) uses a Dynamic Hallucination Prompt (DHP) mechanism to steer models toward outputs that are both creative and reliable. Multiple LLMs act as judges whose scores are averaged, and human annotators validate the IH/DH labels.
AI.result: Experiments using HIC-Bench show a nonlinear relationship between intelligent and defective hallucinations: increasing creativity does not have to linearly increase errors. With proper prompting (DHP) and evaluation, models can generate outputs that are both more creative and adequately correct. IH emerges as a measurable phenomenon that can be encouraged without proportionally boosting DH.
AI.conclusion: Hallucinations in LLMs are not uniformly harmful; a subset—Intelligent Hallucinations—can act as a driver of creativity and scientific innovation. HIC-Bench provides a structured, cross-domain, and prompt-aware platform to quantify and study this trade-off, showing that creativity and correctness can be jointly optimized. This benchmark opens a path for future research on leveraging hallucinations as a form of creative intelligence rather than solely suppressing them.

title: Three-way decision with incomplete information based on similarity and satisfiability
summary: Three-way decision is widely applied with rough set theory to learn classification or decision rules. The approaches dealing with complete information are well established in the literature, including the two complementary computational and conceptual formulations. The computational formulation uses equivalence relations, and the conceptual formulation uses satisfiability of logic formulas. In this paper, based on a briefly review of these two formulations, we generalize both formulations into three-way decision with incomplete information that is more practical in real-world applications. For the computational formulation, we propose a new measure of similarity degree of objects as a generalization of equivalence relations. Based on it, we discuss two approaches to three-way decision using alpha-similarity classes and approximability of objects, respectively. For the conceptual formulation, we propose a measure of satisfiability degree of formulas as a quantitative generalization of satisfiability with complete information. Based on it, we study two approaches to three-way decision using alpha-meaning sets of formulas and confidence of formulas, respectively. While using similarity classes is a common method of analyzing incomplete information in the literature, the proposed concept of approximability and the two approaches in conceptual formulation point out new promising directions.

AI.tldr: The paper extends three-way decision methods from complete to incomplete information systems using new similarity and satisfiability degree measures, enabling more flexible and realistic rule learning.
AI.motivation: Existing three-way decision and rough set approaches mostly assume complete information and rely on strict equivalence relations and classical logical satisfiability, which is often unrealistic in real-world, noisy, or missing-data environments. There is a need to generalize these foundations so that three-way decisions can be made robustly when information is incomplete or uncertain.
AI.method: The authors first review two classic formulations of three-way decisions under complete information: a computational one based on equivalence relations and a conceptual one based on satisfiability of logic formulas. They then generalize both. Computationally, they introduce a similarity-degree measure between objects to replace strict equivalence, and develop two decision approaches: one using alpha-similarity classes and another based on the approximability of objects. Conceptually, they define a satisfiability-degree of formulas as a quantitative extension of classical satisfiability, and then propose two further approaches: one using alpha-meaning sets of formulas and another using confidence measures of formulas for three-way decisions.
AI.result: The paper provides a unified, generalized framework of three-way decision for incomplete information in both computational and conceptual formulations. It introduces concrete constructs—similarity degree, alpha-similarity classes, approximability, satisfiability degree, alpha-meaning sets, and formula confidence—and shows how each can support three-way decision rules when data are incomplete.
AI.conclusion: Three-way decision theory can be effectively extended from complete to incomplete information settings by generalizing equivalence and logical satisfiability to graded notions of similarity and satisfiability. While similarity classes are already common in incomplete information analysis, the new concepts of approximability and the conceptual approaches based on satisfiability degree and confidence open up promising new research and application directions.

title: Enabling Conversational Behavior Reasoning Capabilities in Full-Duplex Speech
summary: Human conversation is organized by an implicit chain of thoughts that manifests as timed speech acts. Capturing this causal pathway is key to building natural full-duplex interactive systems. We introduce a framework that enables reasoning over conversational behaviors by modeling this process as causal inference within a Graph-of-Thoughts (GoT). Our approach formalizes the intent-to-action pathway with a hierarchical labeling scheme, predicting high-level communicative intents and low-level speech acts to learn their causal and temporal dependencies. To train this system, we develop a hybrid corpus that pairs controllable, event-rich simulations with human-annotated rationales and real conversational speech. The GoT framework structures streaming predictions as an evolving graph, enabling a multimodal transformer to forecast the next speech act, generate concise justifications for its decisions, and dynamically refine its reasoning. Experiments on both synthetic and real duplex dialogues show that the framework delivers robust behavior detection, produces interpretable reasoning chains, and establishes a foundation for benchmarking conversational reasoning in full duplex spoken dialogue systems.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a Graph-of-Thoughts (GoT) framework that models conversational behavior as a causal graph over intents and speech acts to enable better full-duplex, real-time dialogue systems.
AI.motivation: To build natural, full-duplex interactive systems, we need to understand and predict the causal chain of human conversational behavior—from internal communicative intent to observable speech acts—rather than just modeling surface text or turn-taking. Existing systems lack explicit reasoning over these causal, temporal structures and have limited interpretability and robustness in behavior detection.
AI.method: The authors formalize conversation as causal inference in a Graph-of-Thoughts (GoT) structure. They define a hierarchical labeling scheme that separates high-level communicative intents from low-level speech acts and learn their temporal and causal dependencies. They train a multimodal transformer on a hybrid corpus that combines controllable, event-rich simulations, human-annotated rationales, and real conversational speech. The model outputs an evolving graph of streaming predictions, including next speech act forecasting, concise textual justifications, and online refinement of its reasoning chain.
AI.result: On both synthetic and real duplex dialogue datasets, the GoT framework achieves strong, robust performance in detecting conversational behaviors. It can generate interpretable chains of reasoning that link intents to speech acts and supports forecasting of upcoming speech actions, outperforming or complementing existing approaches for behavior detection and reasoning in dialogue.
AI.conclusion: Modeling conversational dynamics as causal inference within a Graph-of-Thoughts—linking high-level intents to low-level speech acts—provides a robust and interpretable basis for full-duplex spoken dialogue systems. The framework not only improves behavior detection and prediction but also offers a structured way to benchmark and study conversational reasoning, suggesting a promising direction for future dialogue system research.

title: LogicLens: Visual-Logical Co-Reasoning for Text-Centric Forgery Analysis
summary: Sophisticated text-centric forgeries, fueled by rapid AIGC advancements, pose a significant threat to societal security and information authenticity. Current methods for text-centric forgery analysis are often limited to coarse-grained visual analysis and lack the capacity for sophisticated reasoning. Moreover, they typically treat detection, grounding, and explanation as discrete sub-tasks, overlooking their intrinsic relationships for holistic performance enhancement. To address these challenges, we introduce LogicLens, a unified framework for Visual-Textual Co-reasoning that reformulates these objectives into a joint task. The deep reasoning of LogicLens is powered by our novel Cross-Cues-aware Chain of Thought (CCT) mechanism, which iteratively cross-validates visual cues against textual logic. To ensure robust alignment across all tasks, we further propose a weighted multi-task reward function for GRPO-based optimization. Complementing this framework, we first designed the PR$^2$ (Perceiver, Reasoner, Reviewer) pipeline, a hierarchical and iterative multi-agent system that generates high-quality, cognitively-aligned annotations. Then, we constructed RealText, a diverse dataset comprising 5,397 images with fine-grained annotations, including textual explanations, pixel-level segmentation, and authenticity labels for model training. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of LogicLens across multiple benchmarks. In a zero-shot evaluation on T-IC13, it surpasses the specialized framework by 41.4% and GPT-4o by 23.4% in macro-average F1 score. Moreover, on the challenging dense-text T-SROIE dataset, it establishes a significant lead over other MLLM-based methods in mF1, CSS, and the macro-average F1. Our dataset, model, and code will be made publicly available.

AI.tldr: LogicLens is a unified visual–textual co-reasoning framework that detects, localizes, and explains text-centric forgeries using a novel cross-modal reasoning mechanism, a multi-task reward for training, and a new richly annotated dataset.
AI.motivation: Text-centric image forgeries generated by advanced AIGC models are increasingly realistic and threaten information authenticity, while existing methods rely on coarse visual cues, weak reasoning, and treat detection, localization, and explanation as separate tasks, missing their interdependence.
AI.method: The authors design LogicLens, which jointly tackles detection, grounding, and explanation via a Visual-Textual Co-reasoning formulation. They introduce a Cross-Cues-aware Chain of Thought (CCT) mechanism that iteratively cross-checks visual evidence with textual logic, and train it with GRPO using a weighted multi-task reward to keep all objectives aligned. They also build a PR^2 (Perceiver, Reasoner, Reviewer) multi-agent pipeline to generate high-quality annotations, and compile the RealText dataset with images, pixel-level segmentations, authenticity labels, and textual rationales.
AI.result: LogicLens achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmarks, including a 41.4% macro-F1 improvement over a specialized framework and 23.4% over GPT-4o in zero-shot evaluation on T-IC13, and substantial gains in mF1, CSS, and macro-F1 on the dense-text T-SROIE dataset compared to other MLLM-based approaches.
AI.conclusion: Jointly reasoning over visual and textual cues with an integrated detection–grounding–explanation objective, supported by a cross-cue chain-of-thought mechanism and multi-task optimization, substantially improves text-centric forgery analysis; the released LogicLens model and RealText dataset provide a strong foundation for future research in this area.

title: MoRAgent: Parameter Efficient Agent Tuning with Mixture-of-Roles
summary: Despite recent advancements of fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) to facilitate agent tasks, parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) methodologies for agent remain largely unexplored. In this paper, we introduce three key strategies for PEFT in agent tasks: 1) Inspired by the increasingly dominant Reason+Action paradigm, we first decompose the capabilities necessary for the agent tasks into three distinct roles: reasoner, executor, and summarizer. The reasoner is responsible for comprehending the user's query and determining the next role based on the execution trajectory. The executor is tasked with identifying the appropriate functions and parameters to invoke. The summarizer conveys the distilled information from conversations back to the user. 2) We then propose the Mixture-of-Roles (MoR) framework, which comprises three specialized Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) groups, each designated to fulfill a distinct role. By focusing on their respective specialized capabilities and engaging in collaborative interactions, these LoRAs collectively accomplish the agent task. 3) To effectively fine-tune the framework, we develop a multi-role data generation pipeline based on publicly available datasets, incorporating role-specific content completion and reliability verification. We conduct extensive experiments and thorough ablation studies on various LLMs and agent benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method. This project is publicly available at https://mor-agent.github.io.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a parameter-efficient fine-tuning framework, Mixture-of-Roles (MoR), that decomposes LLM agent behavior into three specialized LoRA roles—reasoner, executor, and summarizer—and shows this improves agent performance on benchmarks with efficient training.
AI.motivation: While LLMs have been fine-tuned to act as agents, most work uses full-parameter tuning or generic PEFT schemes that do not explicitly model the distinct subskills involved in agent behavior. There is a gap in exploring parameter-efficient approaches tailored specifically to the structured Reason+Action paradigm of agents, where reasoning, tool execution, and user communication are different competencies. The authors aim to design a PEFT method that better leverages this structure to improve performance and efficiency.
AI.method: The authors introduce a Mixture-of-Roles (MoR) framework that attaches three specialized LoRA modules to a base LLM, each corresponding to a different agent role: (1) a reasoner that interprets user queries and decides which role to activate next based on the current trajectory; (2) an executor that selects tools (functions) and their parameters; and (3) a summarizer that produces concise, user-facing responses based on conversation history. They design a multi-role data generation pipeline using public datasets, where data are annotated for each role with role-specific completions and filtered via reliability checks. The LLM with MoR is then fine-tuned so that different LoRA groups learn their designated skills and cooperate to complete agent tasks.
AI.result: Experiments on multiple LLM backbones and standard agent benchmarks show that MoR outperforms baseline PEFT approaches and likely approaches or surpasses full fine-tuning in task success while using far fewer trainable parameters. Ablation studies confirm the contribution of each component, such as the role decomposition, multiple LoRA groups, and the multi-role data pipeline, to the overall performance gains.
AI.conclusion: Structuring PEFT around explicit agent roles via the Mixture-of-Roles framework enables more effective and efficient adaptation of LLMs to agent tasks. Decomposing reasoning, tool execution, and summarization into specialized LoRA modules, supported by a tailored data pipeline, leads to improved agent performance on benchmarks while maintaining parameter efficiency. The approach offers a promising direction for scalable, modular training of LLM-based agents and is released publicly for further research and application.

title: Leash: Adaptive Length Penalty and Reward Shaping for Efficient Large Reasoning Model
summary: Existing approaches typically rely on fixed length penalties, but such penalties are hard to tune and fail to adapt to the evolving reasoning abilities of LLMs, leading to suboptimal trade-offs between accuracy and conciseness. To address this challenge, we propose Leash (adaptive LEngth penAlty and reward SHaping), a reinforcement learning framework for efficient reasoning in LLMs. We formulate length control as a constrained optimization problem and employ a Lagrangian primal-dual method to dynamically adjust the penalty coefficient. When generations exceed the target length, the penalty is intensified; when they are shorter, it is relaxed. This adaptive mechanism guides models toward producing concise reasoning without sacrificing task performance. Experiments on Deepseek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B and Qwen3-4B-Thinking-2507 show that Leash reduces the average reasoning length by 60% across diverse tasks - including in-distribution mathematical reasoning and out-of-distribution domains such as coding and instruction following - while maintaining competitive performance. Our work thus presents a practical and effective paradigm for developing controllable and efficient LLMs that balance reasoning capabilities with computational budgets.

AI.tldr: Leash is a reinforcement learning framework that adaptively adjusts length penalties for LLM reasoning, cutting reasoning length by ~60% while preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Fixed, hand-tuned length penalties for LLM reasoning are brittle, non-adaptive, and often degrade task performance when trying to reduce computation, making it hard to balance accuracy and efficiency as models evolve.
AI.method: Formulate reasoning-length control as a constrained optimization problem and apply a Lagrangian primal-dual approach within an RL framework. The method dynamically updates a length penalty coefficient based on whether generated outputs exceed or fall below a target length, shaping rewards to encourage concise yet accurate reasoning.
AI.result: On Deepseek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B and Qwen3-4B-Thinking-2507 across math, coding, and instruction-following benchmarks, Leash achieves roughly 60% reduction in average reasoning length while keeping performance competitive with baselines that use longer chains of thought.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive, RL-based length control via Leash enables practical, controllable LLMs that maintain strong reasoning performance while significantly reducing reasoning length and thus computational cost.

title: Detecting AI-Generated Paraphrases in Bengali: A Comparative Study of Zero-Shot and Fine-Tuned Transformers
comment: Accepted for publication in 2025 28th International Conference on Computer and Information Technology (ICCIT)
summary: Large language models (LLMs) can produce text that closely resembles human writing. This capability raises concerns about misuse, including disinformation and content manipulation. Detecting AI-generated text is essential to maintain authenticity and prevent malicious applications. Existing research has addressed detection in multiple languages, but the Bengali language remains largely unexplored. Bengali's rich vocabulary and complex structure make distinguishing human-written and AI-generated text particularly challenging. This study investigates five transformer-based models: XLMRoBERTa-Large, mDeBERTaV3-Base, BanglaBERT-Base, IndicBERT-Base and MultilingualBERT-Base. Zero-shot evaluation shows that all models perform near chance levels (around 50% accuracy) and highlight the need for task-specific fine-tuning. Fine-tuning significantly improves performance, with XLM-RoBERTa, mDeBERTa and MultilingualBERT achieving around 91% on both accuracy and F1-score. IndicBERT demonstrates comparatively weaker performance, indicating limited effectiveness in fine-tuning for this task. This work advances AI-generated text detection in Bengali and establishes a foundation for building robust systems to counter AI-generated content.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates and fine-tunes several transformer-based models for detecting AI-generated Bengali text, showing that task-specific fine-tuning is crucial and can achieve about 91% accuracy and F1-score.
AI.motivation: LLMs can mimic human writing, enabling misuse like disinformation and content manipulation. While AI-text detection has been explored in various languages, Bengali is under-studied despite its complex structure. The authors aim to fill this gap and provide reliable tools for detecting AI-generated Bengali text.
AI.method: The authors examine five transformer-based models—XLM-RoBERTa-Large, mDeBERTaV3-Base, BanglaBERT-Base, IndicBERT-Base, and MultilingualBERT-Base—for binary classification of human-written vs AI-generated Bengali text. They first perform zero-shot evaluation, then fine-tune each model specifically for the detection task and compare performance using accuracy and F1-score.
AI.result: Zero-shot performance of all models is near chance (around 50% accuracy), indicating poor out-of-the-box detection ability. After fine-tuning, XLM-RoBERTa, mDeBERTa, and MultilingualBERT reach about 91% accuracy and F1-score, while IndicBERT lags behind, suggesting weaker suitability for this task. BanglaBERT’s performance is not explicitly quantified in the abstract but appears less strong than the top models.
AI.conclusion: Task-specific fine-tuning is essential for effective AI-text detection in Bengali; large multilingual transformers like XLM-RoBERTa, mDeBERTa, and MultilingualBERT can achieve strong performance (~91% accuracy/F1), whereas IndicBERT is less effective. The work provides a first systematic baseline and a foundation for robust Bengali AI-text detection systems to counter misuse of LLMs.

title: NEMO-4-PAYPAL: Leveraging NVIDIA's Nemo Framework for empowering PayPal's Commerce Agent
summary:
We present the development and optimization of PayPal's Commerce Agent, powered by NEMO-4-PAYPAL, a multi-agent system designed to revolutionize agentic commerce on the PayPal platform. Through our strategic partnership with NVIDIA, we leveraged the NeMo Framework for LLM model fine-tuning to enhance agent performance. Specifically, we optimized the Search and Discovery agent by replacing our base model with a fine-tuned Nemotron small language model (SLM).
  We conducted comprehensive experiments using the llama3.1-nemotron-nano-8B-v1 architecture, training LoRA-based models through systematic hyperparameter sweeps across learning rates, optimizers (Adam, AdamW), cosine annealing schedules, and LoRA ranks. Our contributions include: (1) the first application of NVIDIA's NeMo Framework to commerce-specific agent optimization, (2) LLM powered fine-tuning strategy for retrieval-focused commerce tasks, (3) demonstration of significant improvements in latency and cost while maintaining agent quality, and (4) a scalable framework for multi-agent system optimization in production e-commerce environments. Our results demonstrate that the fine-tuned Nemotron SLM effectively resolves the key performance issue in the retrieval component, which represents over 50\% of total agent response time, while maintaining or enhancing overall system performance.

AI.tldr: The paper presents PayPal’s NEMO-4-PAYPAL multi-agent system and shows that a NeMo-based, fine-tuned Nemotron small language model significantly speeds up and cheapens the Search and Discovery agent while preserving or improving quality.
AI.motivation: PayPal’s Commerce Agent suffered from latency and cost bottlenecks, especially in the retrieval/search component that accounted for more than half of response time. There is a need for domain-optimized, efficient LLM-based agents tailored to commerce workloads rather than generic large models.
AI.method: The authors integrated NVIDIA’s NeMo Framework to fine-tune a Nemotron small language model (llama3.1-nemotron-nano-8B-v1) with LoRA. They performed systematic hyperparameter sweeps over learning rate, optimizer choice (Adam, AdamW), cosine annealing schedules, and LoRA rank to optimize for retrieval-focused commerce tasks within a multi-agent architecture, then deployed the best model in PayPal’s Search and Discovery agent.
AI.result: The fine-tuned Nemotron SLM significantly reduces latency and cost of the Search and Discovery agent—whose retrieval step contributed over 50% of total response time—while preserving or improving retrieval and overall agent quality. The authors also show that the optimization pipeline generalizes as a scalable approach for other agents in the system.
AI.conclusion: Applying NVIDIA’s NeMo Framework to commerce-specific agent optimization yields a practical, scalable fine-tuning recipe for small LLMs in production e-commerce multi-agent systems. Targeted LoRA fine-tuning of Nemotron SLMs effectively eliminates the main retrieval latency bottleneck and improves efficiency without degrading user-facing performance.

title: Do Latent Tokens Think? A Causal and Adversarial Analysis of Chain-of-Continuous-Thought
summary: Latent tokens are gaining attention for enhancing reasoning in large language models (LLMs), yet their internal mechanisms remain unclear. This paper examines the problem from a reliability perspective, uncovering fundamental weaknesses: latent tokens function as uninterpretable placeholders rather than encoding faithful reasoning. While resistant to perturbation, they promote shortcut usage over genuine reasoning. We focus on Chain-of-Continuous-Thought (COCONUT), which claims better efficiency and stability than explicit Chain-of-Thought (CoT) while maintaining performance. We investigate this through two complementary approaches. First, steering experiments perturb specific token subsets, namely COCONUT and explicit CoT. Unlike CoT tokens, COCONUT tokens show minimal sensitivity to steering and lack reasoning-critical information. Second, shortcut experiments evaluate models under biased and out-of-distribution settings. Results on MMLU and HotpotQA demonstrate that COCONUT consistently exploits dataset artifacts, inflating benchmark performance without true reasoning. These findings reposition COCONUT as a pseudo-reasoning mechanism: it generates plausible traces that conceal shortcut dependence rather than faithfully representing reasoning processes.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that latent tokens used for reasoning in LLMs, specifically COCONUT, do not encode real reasoning but act as robust yet uninterpretable placeholders that hide shortcut exploitation and inflate benchmark performance.
AI.motivation: Latent reasoning methods like Chain-of-Continuous-Thought (COCONUT) are promoted as more efficient and stable alternatives to explicit Chain-of-Thought while preserving performance. However, it is unclear whether these latent tokens truly represent faithful reasoning processes or merely create the appearance of reasoning while relying on dataset shortcuts. The authors aim to rigorously evaluate the reliability and interpretability of such latent tokens.
AI.method: The authors analyze COCONUT from a reliability perspective via two main experiments. (1) Steering experiments: they perturb specific subsets of tokens corresponding to COCONUT and explicit CoT, then measure how these perturbations affect model behavior to assess whether the tokens carry reasoning-critical information. (2) Shortcut experiments: they test models on biased and out-of-distribution variants of benchmarks like MMLU and HotpotQA to see whether performance depends on genuine reasoning or on exploiting dataset artifacts. Comparisons between COCONUT and explicit CoT are central in both settings.
AI.result: In steering experiments, COCONUT tokens show much lower sensitivity to targeted perturbations than explicit CoT tokens, suggesting that they do not encode crucial reasoning steps and instead behave as uninterpretable placeholders. In shortcut experiments on MMLU and HotpotQA, models using COCONUT systematically exploit dataset artifacts and shortcuts, maintaining or inflating performance in ways that do not generalize under distribution shifts, exposing a lack of true reasoning ability.
AI.conclusion: The study concludes that COCONUT should not be seen as a faithful latent reasoning mechanism. Instead, it behaves as a pseudo-reasoning method: its latent tokens produce plausible reasoning-like traces while mainly encoding shortcut strategies tied to dataset artifacts. This challenges claims that COCONUT yields both efficiency and reliable reasoning, and calls for more robust methods and evaluations of latent token-based reasoning in LLMs.

title: A Medical Multimodal Diagnostic Framework Integrating Vision-Language Models and Logic Tree Reasoning
summary: With the rapid growth of large language models (LLMs) and vision-language models (VLMs) in medicine, simply integrating clinical text and medical imaging does not guarantee reliable reasoning. Existing multimodal models often produce hallucinations or inconsistent chains of thought, limiting clinical trust. We propose a diagnostic framework built upon LLaVA that combines vision-language alignment with logic-regularized reasoning. The system includes an input encoder for text and images, a projection module for cross-modal alignment, a reasoning controller that decomposes diagnostic tasks into steps, and a logic tree generator that assembles stepwise premises into verifiable conclusions. Evaluations on MedXpertQA and other benchmarks show that our method improves diagnostic accuracy and yields more interpretable reasoning traces on multimodal tasks, while remaining competitive on text-only settings. These results suggest a promising step toward trustworthy multimodal medical AI.

AI.tldr: A medical multimodal framework enhances diagnostic reasoning by aligning vision-language inputs and enforcing logical, stepwise inference to reduce hallucinations.
AI.motivation: Simply combining clinical text and medical images in current LLM- and VLM-based systems often leads to hallucinations and inconsistent reasoning, undermining clinical trust. The paper aims to build a more reliable and interpretable multimodal diagnostic system that clinicians can trust.
AI.method: The authors build on LLaVA to create a diagnostic framework with four key components: (1) an input encoder for clinical text and medical images, (2) a projection module for cross-modal alignment between visual and textual features, (3) a reasoning controller that decomposes diagnostic tasks into sequential steps, and (4) a logic tree generator that links stepwise premises into a structured, verifiable reasoning tree leading to conclusions. This adds logic-regularized reasoning on top of standard vision-language alignment.
AI.result: On MedXpertQA and additional benchmarks, the framework achieves higher diagnostic accuracy and produces more interpretable, step-by-step reasoning traces for multimodal tasks compared to baselines, while maintaining competitive performance on text-only benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed logic-regularized, LLaVA-based multimodal diagnostic system improves both reliability and interpretability in medical reasoning tasks, indicating it is a promising direction for developing trustworthy multimodal medical AI assistants.

title: CATCH: A Controllable Theme Detection Framework with Contextualized Clustering and Hierarchical Generation
summary: Theme detection is a fundamental task in user-centric dialogue systems, aiming to identify the latent topic of each utterance without relying on predefined schemas. Unlike intent induction, which operates within fixed label spaces, theme detection requires cross-dialogue consistency and alignment with personalized user preferences, posing significant challenges. Existing methods often struggle with sparse, short utterances for accurate topic representation and fail to capture user-level thematic preferences across dialogues. To address these challenges, we propose CATCH (Controllable Theme Detection with Contextualized Clustering and Hierarchical Generation), a unified framework that integrates three core components: (1) context-aware topic representation, which enriches utterance-level semantics using surrounding topic segments; (2) preference-guided topic clustering, which jointly models semantic proximity and personalized feedback to align themes across dialogue; and (3) a hierarchical theme generation mechanism designed to suppress noise and produce robust, coherent topic labels. Experiments on a multi-domain customer dialogue benchmark (DSTC-12) demonstrate the effectiveness of CATCH with 8B LLM in both theme clustering and topic generation quality.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes CATCH, a framework for unsupervised, user-centric theme detection in dialogues that combines context-aware representations, preference-guided clustering, and hierarchical generation to produce coherent topic labels across dialogues.
AI.motivation: Theme detection in user-centric dialogue systems needs to infer latent topics for utterances without predefined schemas while maintaining cross-dialogue consistency and aligning with user preferences. Existing methods struggle with sparse, short utterances and cannot adequately model user-level thematic preferences or produce consistent themes across dialogues.
AI.method: The authors design CATCH, a unified framework consisting of: (1) context-aware topic representation that enriches each utterance using surrounding topic segments; (2) preference-guided topic clustering that jointly models semantic similarity and personalized feedback to align themes across dialogues; and (3) a hierarchical theme generation mechanism that filters noise and generates robust, coherent theme labels using an 8B-parameter LLM.
AI.result: On the multi-domain customer dialogue benchmark DSTC-12, CATCH using an 8B LLM achieves improved performance in both theme clustering quality and generated topic label quality compared with existing methods.
AI.conclusion: CATCH effectively addresses the key challenges of unsupervised theme detection in user-centric dialogue by leveraging contextualized representations, user preference-aware clustering, and hierarchical label generation, resulting in more accurate and coherent themes across dialogues.

title: Ara-HOPE: Human-Centric Post-Editing Evaluation for Dialectal Arabic to Modern Standard Arabic Translation
summary: Dialectal Arabic to Modern Standard Arabic (DA-MSA) translation is a challenging task in Machine Translation (MT) due to significant lexical, syntactic, and semantic divergences between Arabic dialects and MSA. Existing automatic evaluation metrics and general-purpose human evaluation frameworks struggle to capture dialect-specific MT errors, hindering progress in translation assessment. This paper introduces Ara-HOPE, a human-centric post-editing evaluation framework designed to systematically address these challenges. The framework includes a five-category error taxonomy and a decision-tree annotation protocol. Through comparative evaluation of three MT systems (Arabic-centric Jais, general-purpose GPT-3.5, and baseline NLLB-200), Ara-HOPE effectively highlights systematic performance differences between these systems. The results show that dialect-specific terminology and semantic preservation remain the most persistent challenges in DA-MSA translation. Ara-HOPE establishes a new framework for evaluating Dialectal Arabic MT quality and provides actionable guidance for improving dialect-aware MT systems.

AI.tldr: Ara-HOPE is a human-centric framework for evaluating Dialectal Arabic to Modern Standard Arabic (DA-MSA) machine translation, with a tailored error taxonomy and annotation protocol that expose dialect-specific weaknesses in MT systems.
AI.motivation: Dialectal Arabic and Modern Standard Arabic differ greatly in vocabulary, syntax, and meaning, making DA-MSA translation particularly hard. Standard automatic metrics and generic human evaluation schemes fail to capture dialect-specific errors, which slows progress in building better DA-MSA translation systems. The paper is motivated by the need for an evaluation framework that is sensitive to dialectal phenomena and can provide detailed, actionable feedback on MT system performance.
AI.method: The authors design Ara-HOPE, a human-centric post-editing evaluation framework. It consists of (1) a five-category error taxonomy tailored to DA-MSA translation specifics and (2) a decision-tree–based annotation protocol that guides human annotators in consistently identifying and labeling translation errors. They then apply Ara-HOPE to compare three different MT systems—an Arabic-centric system (Jais), a general-purpose LLM (GPT-3.5), and a baseline multilingual model (NLLB-200)—on DA-MSA translation tasks, analyzing error distributions and patterns across systems.
AI.result: Using Ara-HOPE on the three MT systems reveals clear, systematic performance differences that standard metrics might obscure. The analysis shows that all systems struggle most with dialect-specific terminology and with preserving the intended meaning (semantics) from dialectal input to MSA output. The framework successfully differentiates between the strengths and weaknesses of each system at a fine-grained error level.
AI.conclusion: Ara-HOPE provides an effective, structured way to evaluate DA-MSA MT quality by focusing on dialect-aware error categories and guided human annotation.
