It exposes persistent issues like handling dialect-specific terms and maintaining semantic fidelity, and offers insights that can inform the development of more robust, dialect-aware MT models. The framework thus sets a new standard for evaluating Dialectal Arabic MT and offers practical guidance for future system improvements.

title: Democratizing Drug Discovery with an Orchestrated, Knowledge-Driven Multi-Agent Team for User-Guided Therapeutic Design
summary: Therapeutic discovery remains a formidable challenge, impeded by the fragmentation of specialized domains and the execution gap between computational design and physiological validation. Although generative AI offers promise, current models often function as passive assistants rather than as autonomous executors. Here, we introduce OrchestRA, a human-in-the-loop multi-agent platform that unifies biology, chemistry, and pharmacology into an autonomous discovery engine. Unlike static code generators, our agents actively execute simulations and reason the results to drive iterative optimization. Governed by an Orchestrator, a Biologist Agent leverages deep reasoning over a massive knowledge graph (>10 million associations) to pinpoint high-confidence targets; a Chemist Agent autonomously detects structural pockets for de novo design or drug repositioning; and a Pharmacologist Agent evaluates candidates via rigorous physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) simulations. This architecture establishes a dynamic feedback loop where pharmacokinetic and toxicity profiles directly trigger structural reoptimization. By seamlessly integrating autonomous execution with human guidance, OrchestRA democratizes therapeutic design, transforming drug discovery from a stochastic search to a programmable evidence-based engineering discipline.

AI.tldr: OrchestRA is a multi-agent, human-in-the-loop AI platform that autonomously integrates biology, chemistry, and pharmacology to iteratively design and evaluate drug candidates.
AI.motivation: Drug discovery is slow and inefficient due to fragmented expertise across disciplines and a large gap between in silico design and real physiological validation. Existing generative AI tools mostly act as passive assistants or code generators, rather than systems that can autonomously execute experiments, interpret results, and close the loop on design decisions. There is a need for an integrated, programmable framework that actively coordinates biological target selection, molecular design, and pharmacokinetic evaluation.
AI.method: The authors propose OrchestRA, a multi-agent architecture governed by an Orchestrator. It consists of: (1) a Biologist Agent that uses deep reasoning over a large-scale biological knowledge graph (over 10 million associations) to identify promising therapeutic targets; (2) a Chemist Agent that detects structural pockets on targets and performs de novo design or drug repositioning; and (3) a Pharmacologist Agent that runs physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) simulations to assess candidates. The system forms a closed feedback loop where PK and toxicity results directly prompt structural re-optimization, all under a human-in-the-loop supervision model.
AI.result: The abstract claims that OrchestRA successfully operates as an autonomous discovery engine that can carry out simulations, interpret them, and iteratively optimize drug candidates across biology, chemistry, and pharmacology, though specific quantitative performance metrics are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: By integrating autonomous multi-agent execution with human oversight, OrchestRA turns drug discovery into a programmable, evidence-driven engineering workflow rather than a largely stochastic search. The platform is presented as a way to democratize and systematize therapeutic design by unifying disparate expert domains and closing the loop between computational design and physiological evaluation.

title: Five Years of SciCap: What We Learned and Future Directions for Scientific Figure Captioning
comment: Accepted to the 5th Annual AAAI Workshop on AI to Accelerate Science and Engineering (AI2ASE 2026)
summary: Between 2021 and 2025, the SciCap project grew from a small seed-funded idea at The Pennsylvania State University (Penn State) into one of the central efforts shaping the scientific figure-captioning landscape. Supported by a Penn State seed grant, Adobe, and the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, what began as our attempt to test whether domain-specific training, which was successful in text models like SciBERT, could also work for figure captions expanded into a multi-institution collaboration. Over these five years, we curated, released, and continually updated a large collection of figure-caption pairs from arXiv papers, conducted extensive automatic and human evaluations on both generated and author-written captions, navigated the rapid rise of large language models (LLMs), launched annual challenges, and built interactive systems that help scientists write better captions. In this piece, we look back at the first five years of SciCap and summarize the key technical and methodological lessons we learned. We then outline five major unsolved challenges and propose directions for the next phase of research in scientific figure captioning.

AI.tldr: A retrospective overview of the first five years of the SciCap project in scientific figure captioning, highlighting its growth, contributions, and open challenges.
AI.motivation: To investigate whether domain-specific training that proved useful in scientific text models (e.g., SciBERT) can similarly improve scientific figure captioning, and to guide the community by reflecting on lessons learned and remaining challenges.
AI.method: Curate and release a large, evolving dataset of figure–caption pairs from arXiv; train and evaluate captioning models with both automatic and human assessments; organize annual shared tasks; and build interactive caption-authoring tools while tracking the impact of rapidly advancing LLMs.
AI.result: SciCap became a large multi-institution collaboration with widely used datasets, benchmarks, and tools for scientific figure captioning, alongside systematic evaluations of both generated and human-written captions.
AI.conclusion: Domain-focused, data-rich, and community-driven approaches can substantially advance scientific figure captioning, but significant open problems remain; the authors distill technical and methodological lessons from SciCap’s first five years and identify five key unsolved challenges and future research directions.

title: Multiple-play Stochastic Bandits with Prioritized Arm Capacity Sharing
summary: This paper proposes a variant of multiple-play stochastic bandits tailored to resource allocation problems arising from LLM applications, edge intelligence, etc. The model is composed of $M$ arms and $K$ plays. Each arm has a stochastic number of capacities, and each unit of capacity is associated with a reward function. Each play is associated with a priority weight. When multiple plays compete for the arm capacity, the arm capacity is allocated in a larger priority weight first manner. Instance independent and instance dependent regret lower bounds of $Ω( α_1 σ\sqrt{KM T} )$ and $Ω(α_1 σ^2 \frac{M}Δ \ln T)$ are proved, where $α_1$ is the largest priority weight and $σ$ characterizes the reward tail. When model parameters are given, we design an algorithm named \texttt{MSB-PRS-OffOpt} to locate the optimal play allocation policy with a computational complexity of $O(MK^3)$. Utilizing \texttt{MSB-PRS-OffOpt} as a subroutine, an approximate upper confidence bound (UCB) based algorithm is designed, which has instance independent and instance dependent regret upper bounds matching the corresponding lower bound up to factors of $ \sqrt{K \ln KT }$ and $α_1 K^2$ respectively. To this end, we address nontrivial technical challenges arising from optimizing and learning under a special nonlinear combinatorial utility function induced by the prioritized resource sharing mechanism.

AI.tldr: A new multiple-play bandit model for prioritized resource allocation with stochastic capacities is proposed, along with matching regret bounds and efficient algorithms.
AI.motivation: Classical multi-armed and multiple-play bandits do not capture practical resource allocation settings like LLM serving and edge computing, where each resource (arm) has random capacity, multiple users (plays) have different priorities, and capacity must be shared according to these priorities. There is a need for a principled learning framework and algorithms that handle this prioritized resource sharing while providing performance guarantees.
AI.method: The authors define a variant of multiple-play stochastic bandits in which each arm has a stochastic capacity divided into units, each unit yielding a random reward governed by a tail parameter σ, and each play has an associated priority weight. A prioritized resource sharing rule allocates capacity to higher-priority plays first. They analyze regret in this setting, derive instance-independent and instance-dependent lower bounds, and then design an offline optimization algorithm (MSB-PRS-OffOpt) that computes the optimal play allocation in O(MK^3). Building on this, they construct an approximate UCB-style online learning algorithm that repeatedly solves the offline problem with optimistic estimates of the rewards. They tackle the technical difficulty of a nonlinear combinatorial utility function induced by the priority-based sharing rule.
AI.result: They establish regret lower bounds of order Ω(α1 σ√(KMT)) (instance independent) and Ω(α1 σ^2 (M/Δ) ln T) (instance dependent), where α1 is the largest priority weight and σ reflects the reward tail. The MSB-PRS-OffOpt algorithm finds the optimal allocation in polynomial time, O(MK^3). The proposed UCB-based online algorithm achieves instance-independent and instance-dependent regret upper bounds that match the corresponding lower bounds up to multiplicative factors √(K ln(KT)) and α1 K^2, respectively.
AI.conclusion: Prioritized resource sharing in stochastic multiple-play bandits can be modeled and optimized with provable guarantees. By carefully exploiting the problem structure, one can design offline and online algorithms whose regret nearly matches fundamental lower bounds, even under nonlinear combinatorial utilities induced by priority-based capacity allocation. This provides a theoretical foundation for learning-based prioritized resource allocation in applications like LLM serving and edge intelligence.

title: On The Conceptualization and Societal Impact of Cross-Cultural Bias
comment: Term paper for LING 575 (Societal Impacts of Language Technologies)
summary:
Research has shown that while large language models (LLMs) can generate their responses based on cultural context, they are not perfect and tend to generalize across cultures. However, when evaluating the cultural bias of a language technology on any dataset, researchers may choose not to engage with stakeholders actually using that technology in real life, which evades the very fundamental problem they set out to address.
  Inspired by the work done by arXiv:2005.14050v2, I set out to analyse recent literature about identifying and evaluating cultural bias in Natural Language Processing (NLP). I picked out 20 papers published in 2025 about cultural bias and came up with a set of observations to allow NLP researchers in the future to conceptualize bias concretely and evaluate its harms effectively. My aim is to advocate for a robust assessment of the societal impact of language technologies exhibiting cross-cultural bias.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys recent 2025 work on cultural bias in NLP, highlighting that LLMs generalize across cultures and that evaluations often ignore real stakeholders, and proposes observations to help future researchers conceptualize and assess cross-cultural harms more robustly.
AI.motivation: LLMs can use cultural context but still overgeneralize and exhibit cultural bias. Existing evaluations tend to rely purely on datasets and benchmarks without engaging the actual communities affected, which undermines attempts to understand real-world harms. The author is motivated to clarify how cultural bias is identified and evaluated in 2025 NLP research and to promote more socially grounded, stakeholder-aware assessments.
AI.method: The author performs a literature-based analysis: selecting 20 papers published in 2025 on cultural bias in NLP, then synthesizing and comparing how they define cultural bias, what datasets and evaluation setups they use, and how they treat societal impact. From this review, the author derives a set of structured observations or principles for analyzing and evaluating cultural bias in language technologies.
AI.result: From the 20-paper review, the author identifies recurring patterns and gaps: LLMs’ cultural generalizations, limited engagement with affected stakeholders, and shortcomings in current bias evaluation practices. The outcome is a distilled set of observations or guidelines intended to help researchers more concretely define cultural bias, design better evaluations, and link technical findings to actual harms in different cultural contexts.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that contemporary NLP research on cultural bias often insufficiently captures real-world societal impact because it rarely involves stakeholders and tends to rely on abstract benchmarks. It argues for a more robust, harm-focused and culturally grounded assessment framework and offers synthesized observations as a starting point for future work to better conceptualize and evaluate cross-cultural bias in language technologies.

title: Towards Responsible and Explainable AI Agents with Consensus-Driven Reasoning
summary: Agentic AI represents a major shift in how autonomous systems reason, plan, and execute multi-step tasks through the coordination of Large Language Models (LLMs), Vision Language Models (VLMs), tools, and external services. While these systems enable powerful new capabilities, increasing autonomy introduces critical challenges related to explainability, accountability, robustness, and governance, especially when agent outputs influence downstream actions or decisions. Existing agentic AI implementations often emphasize functionality and scalability, yet provide limited mechanisms for understanding decision rationale or enforcing responsibility across agent interactions. This paper presents a Responsible(RAI) and Explainable(XAI) AI Agent Architecture for production-grade agentic workflows based on multi-model consensus and reasoning-layer governance. In the proposed design, a consortium of heterogeneous LLM and VLM agents independently generates candidate outputs from a shared input context, explicitly exposing uncertainty, disagreement, and alternative interpretations. A dedicated reasoning agent then performs structured consolidation across these outputs, enforcing safety and policy constraints, mitigating hallucinations and bias, and producing auditable, evidence-backed decisions. Explainability is achieved through explicit cross-model comparison and preserved intermediate outputs, while responsibility is enforced through centralized reasoning-layer control and agent-level constraints. We evaluate the architecture across multiple real-world agentic AI workflows, demonstrating that consensus-driven reasoning improves robustness, transparency, and operational trust across diverse application domains. This work provides practical guidance for designing agentic AI systems that are autonomous and scalable, yet responsible and explainable by construction.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a responsible and explainable architecture for agentic AI systems using multiple heterogeneous LLM/VLM agents plus a central reasoning agent to achieve consensus, improve safety, and provide auditable decisions.
AI.motivation: Agentic AI systems that coordinate LLMs, VLMs, tools, and services are becoming more autonomous, but current implementations lack sufficient mechanisms for explainability, accountability, robustness, and governance. This is risky when agent outputs drive downstream actions and decisions, so there is a need for architectures that embed responsibility and transparency into these systems by design.
AI.method: The authors design an AI agent architecture where several heterogeneous LLM and VLM agents independently generate candidate outputs from the same input context. Their outputs explicitly capture uncertainty, disagreement, and alternative interpretations. A dedicated reasoning agent then performs structured consolidation: it compares cross-model outputs, applies safety and policy constraints, mitigates hallucinations and bias, and produces a final, auditable decision. Intermediate outputs and cross-model comparisons are preserved to support explainability and post-hoc analysis.
AI.result: When evaluated across multiple real-world agentic AI workflows, the multi-model consensus plus reasoning-layer governance approach yields more robust and transparent agent behavior. The architecture improves operational trust, reduces unsafe or hallucinated outputs, and provides clearer explanations of decisions across diverse applications.
AI.conclusion: A consensus-driven, reasoning-layer-governed architecture can make agentic AI systems both highly autonomous and inherently responsible and explainable. By combining heterogeneous models, explicit uncertainty handling, centralized reasoning control, and preserved intermediate artifacts, practitioners can design production-grade agentic workflows that satisfy requirements for safety, accountability, and transparency.

title: Method Decoration (DeMe): A Framework for LLM-Driven Adaptive Method Generation in Dynamic IoT Environments
summary: Intelligent IoT systems increasingly rely on large language models (LLMs) to generate task-execution methods for dynamic environments. However, existing approaches lack the ability to systematically produce new methods when facing previously unseen situations, and they often depend on fixed, device-specific logic that cannot adapt to changing environmental conditions.In this paper, we propose Method Decoration (DeMe), a general framework that modifies the method-generation path of an LLM using explicit decorations derived from hidden goals, accumulated learned methods, and environmental feedback. Unlike traditional rule augmentation, decorations in DeMe are not hardcoded; instead, they are extracted from universal behavioral principles, experience, and observed environmental differences. DeMe enables the agent to reshuffle the structure of its method path-through pre-decoration, post-decoration, intermediate-step modification, and step insertion-thereby producing context-aware, safety-aligned, and environment-adaptive methods. Experimental results show that method decoration allows IoT devices to derive ore appropriate methods when confronting unknown or faulty operating conditions.

AI.tldr: They propose DeMe, a method-decoration framework that alters LLM-generated task methods for IoT so they adapt to unseen and faulty environments.
AI.motivation: IoT systems using LLMs cannot reliably generate new, safe, and effective task-execution methods when facing previously unseen or faulty situations because they rely on fixed device-specific logic and lack a systematic way to adapt methods to changing environments.
AI.method: Introduce Method Decoration (DeMe), which changes the LLM’s method-generation path by applying “decorations” derived from hidden goals, previously learned methods, and environmental feedback. Decorations are extracted from general behavioral principles and observed differences rather than hardcoded rules, and can be applied as pre-decoration, post-decoration, intermediate-step modification, and step insertion to reshape the method structure.
AI.result: Experiments on IoT devices in unknown or faulty operating conditions show that DeMe enables the generation of more appropriate, context-aware, and safety-aligned methods compared with existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: DeMe provides a general, rule-light framework that systematically decorates and restructures LLM-generated methods, improving adaptability and safety of intelligent IoT systems in dynamic and previously unseen environments.

title: Compliance Rating Scheme: A Data Provenance Framework for Generative AI Datasets
summary: Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) has experienced exponential growth in recent years, partly facilitated by the abundance of large-scale open-source datasets. These datasets are often built using unrestricted and opaque data collection practices. While most literature focuses on the development and applications of GAI models, the ethical and legal considerations surrounding the creation of these datasets are often neglected. In addition, as datasets are shared, edited, and further reproduced online, information about their origin, legitimacy, and safety often gets lost. To address this gap, we introduce the Compliance Rating Scheme (CRS), a framework designed to evaluate dataset compliance with critical transparency, accountability, and security principles. We also release an open-source Python library built around data provenance technology to implement this framework, allowing for seamless integration into existing dataset-processing and AI training pipelines. The library is simultaneously reactive and proactive, as in addition to evaluating the CRS of existing datasets, it equally informs responsible scraping and construction of new datasets.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a Compliance Rating Scheme (CRS) and an accompanying Python library to assess and improve the legal, ethical, and security compliance of datasets used for training generative AI models.
AI.motivation: Generative AI depends heavily on large open-source datasets, many of which are collected with opaque and unrestricted methods. This raises unaddressed ethical and legal concerns regarding transparency, accountability, data provenance, and safety. As datasets are repeatedly shared, edited, and recombined online, information about their origin and compliance is lost, making responsible use and auditing difficult. The authors aim to fill this gap by providing a structured way to evaluate and document dataset compliance.
AI.method: The authors design the Compliance Rating Scheme (CRS), a principled framework with criteria rooted in transparency, accountability, and security for assessing datasets. They also implement CRS as an open-source Python library using data provenance technologies. This library can be integrated into dataset pipelines and AI training workflows to automatically analyze existing datasets and guide the compliant collection and construction of new datasets.
AI.result: The outcome is a formalized CRS framework plus a practical open-source Python library that operationalizes it. The library can compute compliance ratings for existing datasets and provides mechanisms and guidelines for responsible scraping and building datasets in accordance with CRS principles, thereby embedding compliance checks into technical workflows.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that addressing the often-overlooked compliance aspects of dataset creation is crucial for responsible generative AI. By introducing CRS and an accompanying provenance-based Python library, the authors offer both a conceptual framework and a practical tool to enhance transparency, accountability, and security in dataset practices, supporting more ethical and legally sound AI development.

title: Knowledge Reasoning of Large Language Models Integrating Graph-Structured Information for Pest and Disease Control in Tobacco
summary: This paper proposes a large language model (LLM) approach that integrates graph-structured information for knowledge reasoning in tobacco pest and disease control. Built upon the GraphRAG framework, the proposed method enhances knowledge retrieval and reasoning by explicitly incorporating structured information from a domain-specific knowledge graph. Specifically, LLMs are first leveraged to assist in the construction of a tobacco pest and disease knowledge graph, which organizes key entities such as diseases, symptoms, control methods, and their relationships. Based on this graph, relevant knowledge is retrieved and integrated into the reasoning process to support accurate answer generation. The Transformer architecture is adopted as the core inference model, while a graph neural network (GNN) is employed to learn expressive node representations that capture both local and global relational information within the knowledge graph. A ChatGLM-based model serves as the backbone LLM and is fine-tuned using LoRA to achieve parameter-efficient adaptation. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach consistently outperforms baseline methods across multiple evaluation metrics, significantly improving both the accuracy and depth of reasoning, particularly in complex multi-hop and comparative reasoning scenarios.

AI.tldr: Proposes a GraphRAG-based LLM system that injects knowledge-graph structure about tobacco pests/diseases into a ChatGLM backbone, using GNN embeddings to improve multi-hop and comparative reasoning for pest and disease control.
AI.motivation: Traditional LLM-based QA in agricultural pest and disease control often relies on unstructured text retrieval, which struggles with complex, multi-hop, or relation-intensive queries. Tobacco pest and disease management requires precise reasoning over entities like diseases, symptoms, and control methods. There is a need to more explicitly inject structured expert knowledge into LLMs to improve accuracy, depth, and reliability of domain-specific reasoning.
AI.method: 1) Use LLMs to help build a domain-specific knowledge graph for tobacco pests and diseases, encoding entities (diseases, symptoms, control methods) and their relations. 2) Adopt a GraphRAG framework: during retrieval, query the knowledge graph to obtain relevant subgraphs and graph-structured context. 3) Learn node embeddings with a graph neural network that captures local and global graph structure. 4) Integrate these graph-based representations into a Transformer-based inference pipeline with a ChatGLM LLM backbone. 5) Fine-tune the backbone via parameter-efficient LoRA to adapt to the domain. 6) Evaluate against baselines on multiple metrics, focusing on complex reasoning tasks.
AI.result: The integrated GraphRAG + GNN + ChatGLM system outperforms baseline methods across several evaluation metrics. It yields higher answer accuracy and richer reasoning quality, with especially strong gains in scenarios requiring multi-hop and comparative reasoning over the knowledge graph.
AI.conclusion: Explicitly integrating domain-specific, graph-structured knowledge into an LLM via a GraphRAG framework and GNN-augmented representations significantly improves reasoning performance for tobacco pest and disease control tasks. This demonstrates the effectiveness of combining knowledge graphs, graph neural networks, and parameter-efficient LLM fine-tuning for complex, domain-centric question answering.

title: Accelerating Scientific Discovery with Autonomous Goal-evolving Agents
summary: There has been unprecedented interest in developing agents that expand the boundary of scientific discovery, primarily by optimizing quantitative objective functions specified by scientists. However, for grand challenges in science , these objectives are only imperfect proxies. We argue that automating objective function design is a central, yet unmet requirement for scientific discovery agents. In this work, we introduce the Scientific Autonomous Goal-evolving Agent (SAGA) to amend this challenge. SAGA employs a bi-level architecture in which an outer loop of LLM agents analyzes optimization outcomes, proposes new objectives, and converts them into computable scoring functions, while an inner loop performs solution optimization under the current objectives. This bi-level design enables systematic exploration of the space of objectives and their trade-offs, rather than treating them as fixed inputs. We demonstrate the framework through a broad spectrum of applications, including antibiotic design, inorganic materials design, functional DNA sequence design, and chemical process design, showing that automating objective formulation can substantially improve the effectiveness of scientific discovery agents.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes SAGA, a bi-level agent framework where LLMs iteratively redesign and refine scientific objective functions while an inner optimizer searches for solutions, leading to better scientific discovery across multiple domains.
AI.motivation: Current AI-driven scientific discovery systems usually optimize fixed, human-specified objective functions (e.g., scores, properties). For complex scientific problems, these objectives are only rough proxies for what scientists truly care about, and manually refining them is slow and ad hoc. There is a need for agents that can autonomously revise and improve the objectives themselves so that scientific search becomes more aligned with high-level goals.
AI.method: The authors introduce SAGA, a Scientific Autonomous Goal-evolving Agent with a bi-level architecture. In the outer loop, LLM-based agents inspect the results of previous optimization runs, analyze failures or trade-offs, propose refined or entirely new objectives, and translate these into precise, computable scoring functions. In the inner loop, standard optimization methods search for candidate solutions under the current set of objectives. The process iterates, enabling exploration of both solution space and objective space, including their trade-offs.
AI.result: Across several application domains—antibiotic design, inorganic materials discovery, functional DNA sequence design, and chemical process optimization—SAGA is shown to outperform baselines that rely on fixed objectives. Automating the generation and revision of objectives leads to more effective exploration and discovery, yielding higher-quality or more diverse solutions that better match domain-desired properties.
AI.conclusion: Automating objective function design is essential for next-generation scientific discovery agents. SAGA demonstrates that a bi-level architecture where LLMs evolve objectives while optimizers search for solutions can substantially enhance performance across diverse scientific domains, highlighting the value of treating objectives as adaptive, learnable artifacts rather than static inputs.

title: AlignAR: Generative Sentence Alignment for Arabic-English Parallel Corpora of Legal and Literary Texts
summary: High-quality parallel corpora are essential for Machine Translation (MT) research and translation teaching. However, Arabic-English resources remain scarce and existing datasets mainly consist of simple one-to-one mappings. In this paper, we present AlignAR, a generative sentence alignment method, and a new Arabic-English dataset comprising complex legal and literary texts. Our evaluation demonstrates that "Easy" datasets lack the discriminatory power to fully assess alignment methods. By reducing one-to-one mappings in our "Hard" subset, we exposed the limitations of traditional alignment methods. In contrast, LLM-based approaches demonstrated superior robustness, achieving an overall F1-score of 85.5%, a 9% improvement over previous methods. Our datasets and codes are open-sourced at https://github.com/XXX.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces AlignAR, a generative sentence alignment method, and a new challenging Arabic-English legal and literary corpus to better evaluate alignment methods, showing LLM-based approaches outperform traditional ones.
AI.motivation: Existing Arabic-English parallel corpora are scarce and mostly contain simple one-to-one sentence pairs, which are insufficient for thoroughly evaluating sentence alignment methods used in MT research and translation teaching. The authors want more realistic, complex data and stronger alignment techniques.
AI.method: They build a new Arabic-English dataset focused on complex legal and literary texts and explicitly create an "Easy" subset with many one-to-one mappings and a "Hard" subset with fewer one-to-one alignments and more complex relationships. They propose AlignAR, a generative sentence alignment method likely based on large language models, and compare its performance and other LLM-based approaches against traditional alignment methods on both subsets.
AI.result: Experiments show that evaluations on "Easy" datasets do not sufficiently differentiate alignment methods. On the "Hard" subset with reduced one-to-one mappings, traditional methods show clear limitations, while LLM-based methods remain robust. LLM-based approaches reach an overall F1 of 85.5%, which is a 9% absolute improvement over previous state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: Complex, non-trivial parallel corpora are necessary to meaningfully test sentence alignment methods. The proposed AlignAR method and new Arabic-English legal and literary datasets provide a more discriminative benchmark, and LLM-based alignment approaches significantly outperform traditional methods. The resources are released openly to support further research.

title: SpatialBench: Can Agents Analyze Real-World Spatial Biology Data?
summary: Spatial transcriptomics assays are rapidly increasing in scale and complexity, making computational analysis a major bottleneck in biological discovery. Although frontier AI agents have improved dramatically at software engineering and general data analysis, it remains unclear whether they can extract biological insight from messy, real-world spatial datasets. We introduce SpatialBench, a benchmark of 146 verifiable problems derived from practical spatial analysis workflows spanning five spatial technologies and seven task categories. Each problem provides a snapshot of experimental data immediately prior to an analysis step and a deterministic grader that evaluates recovery of a key biological result. Benchmark data on frontier models shows that base model accuracy remains low (20-38% across model families), with strong model-task and model-platform interactions. Harness design has a large empirical effect on performance, indicating that tools, prompts, control flow, and execution environment should be evaluated and improved as first-class objects. SpatialBench serves both as a measurement tool and a diagnostic lens for developing agents that can interact with real spatial datasets faithfully, transparently, and reproducibly.

AI.tldr: SpatialBench is a benchmark of 146 verifiable tasks designed to test whether AI agents can perform realistic biological analyses on spatial transcriptomics data.
AI.motivation: Spatial transcriptomics data are becoming larger and more complex, making computational analysis a key bottleneck. While frontier AI agents excel at coding and general data analysis, it is unknown whether they can robustly extract biological insight from noisy, real-world spatial datasets. A systematic, realistic benchmark is needed to measure and improve agent performance in this domain.
AI.method: The authors construct SpatialBench, a benchmark composed of 146 problems derived from real spatial analysis workflows. These problems cover five spatial transcriptomics technologies and seven categories of analysis tasks. Each task provides raw or intermediate experimental data just before an analysis step and includes a deterministic grader that checks whether a specific biological result is correctly recovered. They then evaluate multiple frontier models on this benchmark and analyze performance across model families, task types, and platforms, as well as the impact of different agent harness designs (tools, prompts, control flow, execution environment).
AI.result: Frontier base models achieve relatively low accuracy on SpatialBench, ranging from 20–38% across different model families. Performance varies strongly depending on the combination of model, task type, and spatial platform. The design of the agent harness—how tools are exposed, how prompts are structured, and how execution is controlled—has a substantial empirical impact on performance.
AI.conclusion: SpatialBench provides a realistic, graded benchmark for testing AI agents on spatial transcriptomics analysis. The low baseline accuracies and strong dependence on model-task-platform combinations and harness design indicate significant room for improvement. The benchmark can be used both to quantify progress and to diagnose where agents fail, guiding the development of more faithful, transparent, and reproducible AI systems for spatial biology.

title: HeartBench: Probing Core Dimensions of Anthropomorphic Intelligence in LLMs
summary: While Large Language Models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable success in cognitive and reasoning benchmarks, they exhibit a persistent deficit in anthropomorphic intelligence-the capacity to navigate complex social, emotional, and ethical nuances. This gap is particularly acute in the Chinese linguistic and cultural context, where a lack of specialized evaluation frameworks and high-quality socio-emotional data impedes progress. To address these limitations, we present HeartBench, a framework designed to evaluate the integrated emotional, cultural, and ethical dimensions of Chinese LLMs. Grounded in authentic psychological counseling scenarios and developed in collaboration with clinical experts, the benchmark is structured around a theory-driven taxonomy comprising five primary dimensions and 15 secondary capabilities. We implement a case-specific, rubric-based methodology that translates abstract human-like traits into granular, measurable criteria through a ``reasoning-before-scoring'' evaluation protocol. Our assessment of 13 state-of-the-art LLMs indicates a substantial performance ceiling: even leading models achieve only 60% of the expert-defined ideal score. Furthermore, analysis using a difficulty-stratified ``Hard Set'' reveals a significant performance decay in scenarios involving subtle emotional subtexts and complex ethical trade-offs. HeartBench establishes a standardized metric for anthropomorphic AI evaluation and provides a methodological blueprint for constructing high-quality, human-aligned training data.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces HeartBench, a benchmark for evaluating Chinese LLMs on anthropomorphic intelligence—specifically emotional, cultural, and ethical capabilities—using counseling-based, expert-designed, rubric-guided assessments.
AI.motivation: LLMs excel on many reasoning tasks but perform poorly on anthropomorphic intelligence, especially in Chinese social, emotional, and ethical contexts. There is no suitable evaluation framework or high-quality socio-emotional dataset for Chinese, making it hard to measure and improve such abilities.
AI.method: The authors create HeartBench, grounded in real psychological counseling scenarios and co-designed with clinical experts. They define a theory-based taxonomy with five primary and 15 secondary capability dimensions, then design a case-specific, rubric-based, reasoning-before-scoring protocol that maps abstract human-like traits to fine-grained measurable criteria. They evaluate 13 state-of-the-art LLMs with this framework, including a difficulty-stratified Hard Set to probe challenging cases with subtle emotions and complex ethics.
AI.result: Across 13 leading LLMs, even the best models only reach about 60% of an expert-defined ideal score on the benchmark, revealing a large gap to human-level anthropomorphic competence. Performance drops markedly on the Hard Set, which focuses on subtle emotional cues and intricate ethical trade-offs.
AI.conclusion: HeartBench provides a standardized, theory-grounded metric for assessing anthropomorphic intelligence in Chinese LLMs and exposes a substantial remaining gap to expert-level behavior. It also offers a general methodological template for building rigorous evaluation benchmarks and high-quality, human-aligned training data in socio-emotional and ethical domains.

title: Pruning as a Game: Equilibrium-Driven Sparsification of Neural Networks
comment: Preprint. Under review / to be submitted to a conference
summary: Neural network pruning is widely used to reduce model size and computational cost. Yet, most existing methods treat sparsity as an externally imposed constraint, enforced through heuristic importance scores or training-time regularization. In this work, we propose a fundamentally different perspective: pruning as an equilibrium outcome of strategic interaction among model components. We model parameter groups such as weights, neurons, or filters as players in a continuous non-cooperative game, where each player selects its level of participation in the network to balance contribution against redundancy and competition. Within this formulation, sparsity emerges naturally when continued participation becomes a dominated strategy at equilibrium. We analyze the resulting game and show that dominated players collapse to zero participation under mild conditions, providing a principled explanation for pruning behavior. Building on this insight, we derive a simple equilibrium-driven pruning algorithm that jointly updates network parameters and participation variables without relying on explicit importance scores. This work focuses on establishing a principled formulation and empirical validation of pruning as an equilibrium phenomenon, rather than exhaustive architectural or large-scale benchmarking. Experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves competitive sparsity-accuracy trade-offs while offering an interpretable, theory-grounded alternative to existing pruning methods.

AI.tldr: The paper reinterprets neural network pruning as an equilibrium outcome of a game among network components, leading to a simple, theory-grounded pruning algorithm where sparsity emerges naturally.
AI.motivation: Traditional pruning methods impose sparsity externally using heuristic importance scores or regularization, lacking a principled explanation of why and how sparsity should emerge. The authors want a theoretical, interpretable framework where pruning is a natural consequence of model component interactions rather than a post-hoc engineering trick.
AI.method: They model groups of parameters (weights, neurons, filters) as players in a continuous non-cooperative game, each choosing a participation level in the network. Players trade off their contribution to performance against redundancy and competition. Sparsity appears when, at equilibrium, continued participation becomes a dominated strategy. They analyze the game to show that dominated players converge to zero participation and derive an algorithm that jointly updates standard network parameters and these participation variables, without heuristic importance scores.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows that under mild assumptions, components that are dominated in this game-theoretic sense collapse to zero participation at equilibrium, giving a principled notion of pruning. Empirically, on standard benchmarks, the algorithm achieves sparsity-accuracy trade-offs comparable to existing methods while being simpler and more interpretable.
AI.conclusion: Viewing pruning as an equilibrium phenomenon yields a principled framework where sparsity naturally arises from strategic interaction among components. The resulting equilibrium-driven pruning algorithm provides competitive performance and interpretability, suggesting an appealing alternative to heuristic or purely empirical pruning techniques, even though large-scale benchmarking is left for future work.

title: TimeBill: Time-Budgeted Inference for Large Language Models
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in time-critical systems, such as robotics, autonomous driving, embodied intelligence, and industrial automation, where generating accurate responses within a given time budget is crucial for decision-making, control, or safety-critical tasks. However, the auto-regressive generation process of LLMs makes it challenging to model and estimate the end-to-end execution time. Furthermore, existing efficient inference methods based on a fixed key-value (KV) cache eviction ratio struggle to adapt to varying tasks with diverse time budgets, where an improper eviction ratio may lead to incomplete inference or a drop in response performance. In this paper, we propose TimeBill, a novel time-budgeted inference framework for LLMs that balances the inference efficiency and response performance. To be more specific, we propose a fine-grained response length predictor (RLP) and an execution time estimator (ETE) to accurately predict the end-to-end execution time of LLMs. Following this, we develop a time-budgeted efficient inference approach that adaptively adjusts the KV cache eviction ratio based on execution time prediction and the given time budget. Finally, through extensive experiments, we demonstrate the advantages of TimeBill in improving task completion rate and maintaining response performance under various overrun strategies.

AI.tldr: TimeBill is a framework that makes large language models meet strict time budgets by predicting response length and execution time and then dynamically adjusting KV-cache eviction during decoding.
AI.motivation: LLMs are being used in time-critical applications (e.g., robotics, autonomous driving, industrial automation) where answers must arrive within a strict time budget for safety and control. Existing autoregressive decoding makes end-to-end latency hard to predict, and current efficient-inference methods use a fixed KV-cache eviction ratio that cannot adapt to different prompts or time budgets, causing missed deadlines or degraded answer quality.
AI.method: The authors design TimeBill, which has two main predictive components: (1) a fine-grained Response Length Predictor (RLP) that forecasts how many tokens the model will generate, and (2) an Execution Time Estimator (ETE) that predicts the end-to-end latency given model, hardware, cache state, and predicted length. Using these predictions, they implement a time-budgeted inference scheme that dynamically adjusts the KV-cache eviction ratio during generation so that decoding fits within the available time while preserving as much context as possible.
AI.result: Experiments across different workloads and overrun (deadline-miss) handling strategies show that TimeBill improves task completion rate—more requests finish within their time budgets—while maintaining or only slightly degrading response quality compared to baselines with fixed KV-cache eviction or without time-aware control.
AI.conclusion: TimeBill enables LLMs to operate more reliably in time-critical settings by accurately modeling their execution time and adaptively managing KV-cache usage according to a given time budget, achieving a better balance between deadline adherence and response quality than existing fixed-parameter methods.

title: From Questions to Clinical Recommendations: Large Language Models Driving Evidence-Based Clinical Decision Making
summary: Clinical evidence, derived from rigorous research and data analysis, provides healthcare professionals with reliable scientific foundations for informed decision-making. Integrating clinical evidence into real-time practice is challenging due to the enormous workload, complex professional processes, and time constraints. This highlights the need for tools that automate evidence synthesis to support more efficient and accurate decision making in clinical settings. This study introduces Quicker, an evidence-based clinical decision support system powered by large language models (LLMs), designed to automate evidence synthesis and generate clinical recommendations modeled after standard clinical guideline development processes. Quicker implements a fully automated chain that covers all phases, from questions to clinical recommendations, and further enables customized decision-making through integrated tools and interactive user interfaces. To evaluate Quicker's capabilities, we developed the Q2CRBench-3 benchmark dataset, based on clinical guideline development records for three different diseases. Experimental results highlighted Quicker's strong performance, with fine-grained question decomposition tailored to user preferences, retrieval sensitivities comparable to human experts, and literature screening performance approaching comprehensive inclusion of relevant studies. In addition, Quicker-assisted evidence assessment effectively supported human reviewers, while Quicker's recommendations were more comprehensive and logically coherent than those of clinicians. In system-level testing, collaboration between a single reviewer and Quicker reduced the time required for recommendation development to 20-40 minutes. In general, our findings affirm the potential of Quicker to help physicians make quicker and more reliable evidence-based clinical decisions.

AI.tldr: The paper presents Quicker, a large language model–powered system that automates end-to-end evidence synthesis and clinical recommendation generation, significantly speeding up and improving evidence-based clinical decision-making.
AI.motivation: Clinical practice relies on up‑to‑date, high‑quality evidence, but integrating clinical evidence into real-time decisions is difficult because guideline-style evidence synthesis is time-consuming, labor-intensive, and requires specialized expertise. Clinicians face heavy workloads, complex workflows, and limited time, so they often cannot perform systematic evidence searches, appraisals, and recommendation drafting at the point of care. There is a need for automated tools that can emulate guideline development workflows to rapidly synthesize evidence and support clinicians in making accurate, evidence-based decisions.
AI.method: The authors design and implement Quicker, an evidence-based clinical decision support system built on large language models. Quicker automates the full pipeline from a clinician’s question to final clinical recommendations, mirroring standard guideline development processes. Core components include: (1) fine-grained question decomposition, taking user preferences into account; (2) retrieval of relevant literature; (3) automated literature screening; (4) evidence assessment to support human reviewers; and (5) recommendation generation with interactive tools and interfaces for customized decision-making. To systematically evaluate performance, they construct Q2CRBench-3, a benchmark derived from clinical guideline development records for three diseases, and then run experiments comparing Quicker’s performance with that of human clinicians and reviewers at multiple steps of the pipeline.
AI.result: On the Q2CRBench-3 benchmark, Quicker shows strong capabilities: it decomposes clinical questions in a fine-grained manner aligned with user preferences; its literature retrieval sensitivity is comparable to that of human experts; and its automated screening captures nearly all relevant studies, approaching comprehensive inclusion. When assisting human reviewers in evidence assessment, Quicker effectively supports their work, and its automatically generated clinical recommendations are more comprehensive and logically coherent than those of clinicians working unaided. System-level evaluations further show that a single human reviewer collaborating with Quicker can produce clinical recommendations in about 20–40 minutes, representing a substantial reduction in development time relative to traditional guideline workflows.
AI.conclusion: Quicker demonstrates that large language models can power an end-to-end, guideline-style evidence synthesis and recommendation system that materially improves the speed and quality of evidence-based clinical decision-making. Its performance across question decomposition, retrieval, screening, assessment support, and recommendation generation suggests that such systems can complement clinicians, enabling faster, more reliable, and more comprehensive evidence-based recommendations. The findings support Quicker’s potential as a practical clinical decision support tool and point toward broader adoption of LLM-driven automation in guideline development and point-of-care evidence synthesis.

title: Bridging the Copyright Gap: Do Large Vision-Language Models Recognize and Respect Copyrighted Content?
summary: Large vision-language models (LVLMs) have achieved remarkable advancements in multimodal reasoning tasks. However, their widespread accessibility raises critical concerns about potential copyright infringement. Will LVLMs accurately recognize and comply with copyright regulations when encountering copyrighted content (i.e., user input, retrieved documents) in the context? Failure to comply with copyright regulations may lead to serious legal and ethical consequences, particularly when LVLMs generate responses based on copyrighted materials (e.g., retrieved book experts, news reports). In this paper, we present a comprehensive evaluation of various LVLMs, examining how they handle copyrighted content -- such as book excerpts, news articles, music lyrics, and code documentation when they are presented as visual inputs. To systematically measure copyright compliance, we introduce a large-scale benchmark dataset comprising 50,000 multimodal query-content pairs designed to evaluate how effectively LVLMs handle queries that could lead to copyright infringement. Given that real-world copyrighted content may or may not include a copyright notice, the dataset includes query-content pairs in two distinct scenarios: with and without a copyright notice. For the former, we extensively cover four types of copyright notices to account for different cases. Our evaluation reveals that even state-of-the-art closed-source LVLMs exhibit significant deficiencies in recognizing and respecting the copyrighted content, even when presented with the copyright notice. To solve this limitation, we introduce a novel tool-augmented defense framework for copyright compliance, which reduces infringement risks in all scenarios. Our findings underscore the importance of developing copyright-aware LVLMs to ensure the responsible and lawful use of copyrighted content.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how large vision-language models handle copyrighted visual content and proposes a tool-based framework to improve copyright compliance.
AI.motivation: As LVLMs become widely accessible and used for multimodal reasoning, there is a growing risk that they may inadvertently infringe copyright when generating outputs based on copyrighted inputs such as book excerpts, news, lyrics, or code shown as images. There is a lack of systematic understanding and benchmarks for how well current models recognize and respect copyright, especially when content may or may not include explicit copyright notices.
AI.method: The authors construct a large-scale benchmark of 50,000 multimodal query–content pairs where copyrighted materials (e.g., book excerpts, news articles, music lyrics, code documentation) are presented visually. They design queries that could trigger copyright-infringing outputs and consider two settings: with and without copyright notices, covering four types of notices. They systematically evaluate multiple LVLMs, including state-of-the-art closed-source ones, on this benchmark. Based on observed deficiencies, they propose a tool-augmented defense framework that connects LVLMs to external tools or rules to better detect copyrighted materials and enforce compliant behaviors.
AI.result: The evaluation shows that existing LVLMs, even top closed-source models, frequently fail to recognize and correctly handle copyrighted content. They often do not comply with copyright constraints, including in cases where explicit copyright notices are present in the visual input. The proposed tool-augmented framework significantly reduces copyright infringement risks across different scenarios in the benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Current LVLMs are not reliably copyright-aware and pose legal and ethical risks when interacting with copyrighted visual content. A tool-augmented defense framework can substantially improve compliance, highlighting the necessity of integrating copyright-awareness mechanisms into LVLMs for responsible and lawful deployment.

title: CricBench: A Multilingual Benchmark for Evaluating LLMs in Cricket Analytics
summary: Cricket is the second most popular sport globally, commanding a massive following of over 2.5 billion fans globally. Enthusiasts and analysts frequently seek advanced statistical insights, such as long-term historical performance trends or complex player comparisons, that are often unavailable through standard web searches. While Large Language Models (LLMs) have advanced significantly in Text-to-SQL tasks, their capability to handle the domain-specific nuances, complex schema variations, and multilingual requirements inherent to sports analytics remains under-explored. To investigate this potential capability gap, we present CricBench, a comprehensive benchmark suite for evaluating LLMs on specialized cricket data. To curate a "Gold Standard" dataset, we collaborate with domain experts in cricket and SQL to manually author complex queries, ensuring logical correctness. Recognizing linguistic diversity, we construct the benchmark in both English and Hindi, establishing a framework that is open for further extension to other regional languages. We evaluate six state-of-the-art models, including GPT-4o, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and open-source models, using a strict evaluation protocol. Our results reveal that high performance on general benchmarks does not guarantee success in specialized domains. While the open-weights reasoning model DeepSeek R1 achieves state-of-the-art performance (50.6%), surpassing proprietary giants like Claude 3.7 Sonnet (47.7%) and GPT-4o (33.7%), it still exhibits a significant accuracy drop when moving from general benchmarks (BIRD) to CricBench. Furthermore, we observe that code-mixed Hindi queries frequently yield parity or higher accuracy compared to English, challenging the assumption that English is the optimal prompt language for specialized SQL tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CricBench, a benchmark to evaluate how well LLMs handle complex, domain-specific cricket Text-to-SQL queries in multiple languages, and shows that strong general performance does not transfer reliably to this specialized setting.
AI.motivation: Existing Text-to-SQL benchmarks focus on general domains and mostly English, but cricket fans and analysts need sophisticated, historically grounded, and often multilingual analytics that current tools and benchmarks do not support. The authors want to understand whether state-of-the-art LLMs can handle the nuanced, schema-heavy, and multilingual requirements of real-world cricket statistics analysis, and to expose any performance gaps that general benchmarks might hide.
AI.method: They build CricBench, a specialized Text-to-SQL benchmark over complex cricket databases. Domain experts in both cricket and SQL manually author logically correct, complex queries to serve as gold-standard references. The benchmark is created in both English and Hindi (including code-mixed Hindi), enabling multilingual evaluation. They then evaluate six advanced LLMs—such as GPT-4o, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and the open-weight reasoning model DeepSeek R1—using a strict evaluation protocol, and compare their performance on CricBench with their performance on a popular general Text-to-SQL benchmark (BIRD).
AI.result: DeepSeek R1 attains the highest accuracy on CricBench (50.6%), outperforming proprietary models like Claude 3.7 Sonnet (47.7%) and GPT-4o (33.7%). However, all models show a substantial drop in accuracy when moving from general benchmarks like BIRD to the specialized CricBench tasks, indicating limited transfer of general Text-to-SQL competence to this domain. Additionally, the experiments reveal that code-mixed Hindi queries often perform on par with or better than English queries, suggesting that English is not always the best prompting language for specialized SQL tasks in multilingual settings.
AI.conclusion: CricBench exposes a notable gap between LLM performance on general Text-to-SQL benchmarks and real-world, domain-specific cricket analytics needs. Even the best current models struggle with the schema complexity and domain nuances, and language choice (including code-mixed Hindi) can significantly affect performance. The benchmark provides a foundation for future work on more robust, domain-aware, and multilingual Text-to-SQL systems, and cautions against relying solely on general benchmarks to judge model readiness for specialized applications.

title: Explainable Statute Prediction via Attention-based Model and LLM Prompting
summary: In this paper, we explore the problem of automatic statute prediction where for a given case description, a subset of relevant statutes are to be predicted. Here, the term "statute" refers to a section, a sub-section, or an article of any specific Act. Addressing this problem would be useful in several applications such as AI-assistant for lawyers and legal question answering system. For better user acceptance of such Legal AI systems, we believe the predictions should also be accompanied by human understandable explanations. We propose two techniques for addressing this problem of statute prediction with explanations -- (i) AoS (Attention-over-Sentences) which uses attention over sentences in a case description to predict statutes relevant for it and (ii) LLMPrompt which prompts an LLM to predict as well as explain relevance of a certain statute. AoS uses smaller language models, specifically sentence transformers and is trained in a supervised manner whereas LLMPrompt uses larger language models in a zero-shot manner and explores both standard as well as Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting techniques. Both these models produce explanations for their predictions in human understandable forms. We compare statute prediction performance of both the proposed techniques with each other as well as with a set of competent baselines, across two popular datasets. Also, we evaluate the quality of the generated explanations through an automated counter-factual manner as well as through human evaluation.

AI.tldr: Paper tackles automatic prediction of relevant legal statutes from case descriptions and generating human-understandable explanations.
AI.motivation: Legal professionals and users of legal AI systems need tools that can automatically identify which statutes apply to a described case, but simple predictions without explanations hinder trust and usability. There is a gap for methods that not only predict relevant statutes accurately but also provide clear, human-understandable explanations supporting those predictions.
AI.method: The authors propose two complementary techniques. (1) AoS (Attention-over-Sentences): a supervised model built on smaller language models/sentence transformers that uses sentence-level attention over the case description to predict relevant statutes and uses these attention weights to form explanations. (2) LLMPrompt: a zero-shot method based on large language models prompted to both predict relevant statutes and explain their relevance, exploring standard prompting and Chain-of-Thought prompting. Both methods are evaluated on two public datasets and their explanatory outputs are assessed via automated counterfactual tests and human evaluation.
AI.result: Both AoS and LLMPrompt can generate human-understandable explanations while performing statute prediction. Their predictive performance is compared against each other and against strong baselines on two datasets, and the explanation quality is shown to be reasonable according to both automated counterfactual evaluation and human judgments.
AI.conclusion: It is feasible to design legal AI systems that not only predict relevant statutes from case descriptions but also generate understandable explanations. AoS offers a supervised, smaller-model approach using sentence attention, while LLMPrompt offers a zero-shot large-language-model-based alternative leveraging prompting and Chain-of-Thought. The comparative and explanatory evaluation suggests these are promising directions for interpretable statute prediction in practical legal applications.

title: Accelerate Speculative Decoding with Sparse Computation in Verification
summary: Speculative decoding accelerates autoregressive language model inference by verifying multiple draft tokens in parallel. However, the verification stage often becomes the dominant computational bottleneck, especially for long-context inputs and mixture-of-experts (MoE) models. Existing sparsification methods are designed primarily for standard token-by-token autoregressive decoding to remove substantial computational redundancy in LLMs. This work systematically adopts different sparse methods on the verification stage of the speculative decoding and identifies structured redundancy across multiple dimensions. Based on these observations, we propose a sparse verification framework that jointly sparsifies attention, FFN, and MoE components during the verification stage to reduce the dominant computation cost. The framework further incorporates an inter-draft token and inter-layer retrieval reuse strategy to further reduce redundant computation without introducing additional training. Extensive experiments across summarization, question answering, and mathematical reasoning datasets demonstrate that the proposed methods achieve favorable efficiency-accuracy trade-offs, while maintaining stable acceptance length.

AI.tldr: The paper accelerates speculative decoding in language models by sparsifying and reusing computation in the verification stage, cutting cost while preserving accuracy and acceptance length.
AI.motivation: Speculative decoding speeds up autoregressive LLMs by drafting multiple tokens and then verifying them in parallel, but the verification stage becomes the main computational bottleneck, especially for long contexts and MoE models. Existing sparsification techniques mainly target standard token-by-token decoding and do not fully exploit redundancies specific to speculative verification, leaving significant efficiency gains untapped.
AI.method: The authors systematically apply and study different sparsification methods on the verification stage of speculative decoding, analyzing structured redundancy across attention, FFN, and MoE components. They then design a unified sparse verification framework that jointly sparsifies these components during verification and introduces two reuse mechanisms: inter-draft token retrieval reuse (sharing computation across different drafted tokens) and inter-layer retrieval reuse (sharing computation across layers). The framework operates without additional training, acting as an inference-time optimization.
AI.result: Across tasks including summarization, question answering, and mathematical reasoning, the proposed sparse verification framework reduces the dominant compute cost of speculative decoding verification while achieving favorable efficiency–accuracy trade-offs. Experimental results show that accuracy is largely preserved and the acceptance length—the number of draft tokens accepted per verification step—remains stable, indicating that the speedups do not come at the expense of speculative decoding effectiveness.
AI.conclusion: The paper demonstrates that the verification stage in speculative decoding contains substantial structured redundancy that can be exploited via joint sparsification and reuse strategies. By sparsifying attention, FFN, and MoE and adding inter-draft and inter-layer retrieval reuse, the framework significantly accelerates speculative decoding inference without retraining and with minimal impact on accuracy or acceptance length. This suggests a practical path to more efficient deployment of LLMs, particularly for long-context and MoE settings.

title: SWE-RM: Execution-free Feedback For Software Engineering Agents
summary: Execution-based feedback like unit testing is widely used in the development of coding agents through test-time scaling (TTS) and reinforcement learning (RL). This paradigm requires scalable and reliable collection of unit test cases to provide accurate feedback, and the resulting feedback is often sparse and cannot effectively distinguish between trajectories that are both successful or both unsuccessful. In contrast, execution-free feedback from reward models can provide more fine-grained signals without depending on unit test cases. Despite this potential, execution-free feedback for realistic software engineering (SWE) agents remains underexplored. Aiming to develop versatile reward models that are effective across TTS and RL, however, we observe that two verifiers with nearly identical TTS performance can nevertheless yield very different results in RL. Intuitively, TTS primarily reflects the model's ability to select the best trajectory, but this ability does not necessarily generalize to RL. To address this limitation, we identify two additional aspects that are crucial for RL training: classification accuracy and calibration. We then conduct comprehensive controlled experiments to investigate how to train a robust reward model that performs well across these metrics. In particular, we analyze the impact of various factors such as training data scale, policy mixtures, and data source composition. Guided by these investigations, we introduce SWE-RM, an accurate and robust reward model adopting a mixture-of-experts architecture with 30B total parameters and 3B activated during inference. SWE-RM substantially improves SWE agents on both TTS and RL performance. For example, it increases the accuracy of Qwen3-Coder-Flash from 51.6% to 62.0%, and Qwen3-Coder-Max from 67.0% to 74.6% on SWE-Bench Verified using TTS, achieving new state-of-the-art performance among open-source models.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes SWE-RM, a large, execution-free reward model that provides fine-grained feedback for software engineering agents, improving both test-time scaling and RL training and achieving state-of-the-art results on SWE-Bench Verified.
AI.motivation: Current coding agents mostly rely on execution-based feedback via unit tests for test-time scaling and RL. This feedback is sparse, depends on scalable unit test collection, and often fails to distinguish between similarly good or bad trajectories. Execution-free reward models can give richer, more continuous signals without unit tests, but their use for realistic SWE agents is underexplored and models that look good under TTS can behave very differently in RL. The authors aim to understand what makes a reward model robust across both TTS and RL and to design such a model.
AI.method: The authors first disentangle different desiderata for reward models beyond simple TTS performance, highlighting the roles of trajectory classification accuracy and calibration for RL. They perform controlled experiments varying training data scale, mixtures of policies used to generate trajectories, and the composition and sources of data, to see how these factors affect TTS, accuracy, and calibration. Based on their findings, they design SWE-RM, a mixture-of-experts reward model with 30B total parameters but only 3B active during inference, trained to provide execution-free feedback on SWE tasks.
AI.result: Empirical studies show that verifiers with similar TTS performance can diverge significantly in RL outcomes, underscoring the need for better-calibrated and more accurate reward models. The proposed SWE-RM demonstrates strong robustness across TTS, classification accuracy, and calibration metrics. When used to guide SWE agents, SWE-RM substantially boosts performance: for instance, Qwen3-Coder-Flash accuracy on SWE-Bench Verified improves from 51.6% to 62.0%, and Qwen3-Coder-Max from 67.0% to 74.6% under TTS, setting new SOTA among open-source models.
AI.conclusion: Execution-free reward models can effectively complement or replace execution-based unit tests for training and evaluating SWE agents, provided they are designed with RL-specific requirements like accuracy and calibration in mind. Through systematic analysis of data and training factors, the authors build SWE-RM, a mixture-of-experts reward model that is both scalable and robust, and that significantly advances state-of-the-art performance on standard SWE benchmarks in both TTS and RL settings.

title: Broken Words, Broken Performance: Effect of Tokenization on Performance of LLMs
comment: International Joint Conference on Natural Language Processing & Asia-Pacific Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics (IJCNLP-AACL 2025)
summary: Tokenization is the first step in training any Large Language Model (LLM), where the text is split into a sequence of tokens as per the model's fixed vocabulary. This tokenization in LLMs is different from the traditional tokenization in NLP where the text is split into a sequence of "natural" words. In LLMs, a natural word may also be broken into multiple tokens due to limited vocabulary size of the LLMs (e.g., Mistral's tokenizer splits "martial" into "mart" and "ial"). In this paper, we hypothesize that such breaking of natural words negatively impacts LLM performance on various NLP tasks. To quantify this effect, we propose a set of penalty functions that compute a tokenization penalty for a given text for a specific LLM, indicating how "bad" the tokenization is. We establish statistical significance of our hypothesis on multiple NLP tasks for a set of different LLMs.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that when LLM tokenizers split natural words into multiple subword tokens, it can hurt model performance, and introduces penalty functions to measure how problematic a given tokenization is, then validates this on several NLP tasks and models.
AI.motivation: LLMs use subword tokenization with fixed vocabularies, which often splits a single natural word into multiple tokens. The authors suspect that such unnatural word breaking degrades performance on downstream NLP tasks, but this effect has not been systematically quantified. They want a principled way to measure and empirically test how harmful tokenization fragmentation is.
AI.method: They define several penalty functions that, given a text and a specific LLM’s tokenizer, compute a scalar “tokenization penalty” representing how badly natural words are fragmented into multiple tokens. Using these penalties, they analyze multiple NLP tasks and a range of LLMs, correlating levels of tokenization penalty with model performance. They perform statistical tests to determine if higher penalties are significantly associated with worse performance.
AI.result: Across multiple NLP tasks and different LLMs, they find a statistically significant negative relationship between tokenization quality (as captured by their penalty measures) and model performance. Texts or vocabularies that result in more frequent or severe splitting of natural words tend to show worse LLM performance, and these trends are robust under their statistical analysis.
AI.conclusion: The work supports the hypothesis that breaking natural words into multiple tokens can harm LLM performance and that this effect can be quantified via their proposed penalty functions. This suggests that tokenizer design and tokenization quality are important levers for improving LLM effectiveness and that future models should consider minimizing harmful word fragmentation.

title: Self-attention vector output similarities reveal how machines pay attention
summary: The self-attention mechanism has significantly advanced the field of natural language processing, facilitating the development of advanced language-learning machines. Although its utility is widely acknowledged, the precise mechanisms of self-attention underlying its advanced learning and the quantitative characterization of this learning process remains an open research question. This study introduces a new approach for quantifying information processing within the self-attention mechanism. The analysis conducted on the BERT-12 architecture reveals that, in the final layers, the attention map focuses on sentence separator tokens, suggesting a practical approach to text segmentation based on semantic features. Based on the vector space emerging from the self-attention heads, a context similarity matrix, measuring the scalar product between two token vectors was derived, revealing distinct similarities between different token vector pairs within each head and layer. The findings demonstrated that different attention heads within an attention block focused on different linguistic characteristics, such as identifying token repetitions in a given text or recognizing a token of common appearance in the text and its surrounding context. This specialization is also reflected in the distribution of distances between token vectors with high similarity as the architecture progresses. The initial attention layers exhibit substantially long-range similarities; however, as the layers progress, a more short-range similarity develops, culminating in a preference for attention heads to create strong similarities within the same sentence. Finally, the behavior of individual heads was analyzed by examining the uniqueness of their most common tokens in their high similarity elements. Each head tends to focus on a unique token from the text and builds similarity pairs centered around it.

AI.tldr: The paper quantitatively analyzes how self-attention in BERT processes information, showing head-wise specialization, evolving from long-range to local (sentence-level) similarities, and a focus on separator tokens for semantic segmentation.
AI.motivation: While self-attention is known to be powerful in NLP models like BERT, the exact internal mechanisms, especially how information is processed and represented across layers and heads, are not well understood. The authors want a quantitative way to characterize these processes, to explain what attention heads learn and how their behavior changes across layers.
AI.method: They study a BERT-12 model by constructing, for each self-attention head and layer, a context similarity matrix based on scalar products between token vectors. They then analyze attention maps (e.g., where attention mass is placed, such as on separator tokens), similarity patterns between token pairs, and the distribution of distances between highly similar token vectors across layers. They also inspect which specific tokens each head most strongly associates (high-similarity pairs) to infer functional specialization.
AI.result: They find that in higher layers, attention maps strongly focus on sentence separator tokens, indicating that the model implicitly segments text semantically. Different heads specialize in distinct linguistic roles, such as detecting repeated tokens or tokens that commonly appear with certain contexts. The distance distribution of highly similar token pairs evolves: early layers show many long-range similarities, while later layers increasingly emphasize local, especially intra-sentence, similarities.
