Each head tends to anchor on a particular token type or specific token and builds similarity structures around it.
AI.conclusion: Self-attention in BERT exhibits clear, quantifiable specialization across heads and layers. Early layers capture broad, long-range relationships, whereas later layers focus on local and sentence-level structure, often mediated by separator tokens. Individual heads act as specialized detectors centered on particular tokens or linguistic phenomena. The proposed similarity-based analysis framework offers a way to interpret and quantify these internal processes of self-attention.

title: Context as a Tool: Context Management for Long-Horizon SWE-Agents
summary: Agents based on large language models have recently shown strong potential on real-world software engineering (SWE) tasks that require long-horizon interaction with repository-scale codebases. However, most existing agents rely on append-only context maintenance or passively triggered compression heuristics, which often lead to context explosion, semantic drift, and degraded reasoning in long-running interactions. We propose CAT, a new context management paradigm that elevates context maintenance to a callable tool integrated into the decision-making process of agents. CAT formalizes a structured context workspace consisting of stable task semantics, condensed long-term memory, and high-fidelity short-term interactions, and enables agents to proactively compress historical trajectories into actionable summaries at appropriate milestones. To support context management for SWE-agents, we propose a trajectory-level supervision framework, CAT-GENERATOR, based on an offline data construction pipeline that injects context-management actions into complete interaction trajectories. Using this framework, we train a context-aware model, SWE-Compressor. Experiments on SWE-Bench-Verified demonstrate that SWE-Compressor reaches a 57.6% solved rate and significantly outperforms ReAct-based agents and static compression baselines, while maintaining stable and scalable long-horizon reasoning under a bounded context budget.

AI.tldr: Introduces CAT, a proactive context-management paradigm and a learned SWE-Compressor model that significantly improves long-horizon LLM agents on software-engineering tasks under tight context limits.
AI.motivation: LLM-based software agents must reason over large, repository-scale codebases through long interactions. Existing agents typically grow their context window in an append-only way or rely on simple, passive compression rules. This causes context bloat, loss of important semantics, and weaker reasoning as interactions get longer. The paper aims to create a principled, learnable mechanism for managing and compressing context so agents can stay effective over long horizons within fixed context budgets.
AI.method: They propose CAT, which treats context maintenance as an explicit, callable tool inside the agent’s decision loop. CAT defines a structured context workspace with (1) stable task semantics, (2) compressed long-term memory, and (3) detailed short-term interaction history. Agents can proactively invoke CAT to compress past trajectories into concise, actionable summaries at suitable checkpoints. To train agents to manage context, they introduce CAT-GENERATOR, an offline data pipeline that augments complete interaction trajectories with labeled context-management actions. Using these generated trajectories, they train SWE-Compressor, a context-aware model that learns when and how to compress and organize interaction history for SWE tasks.
AI.result: On the SWE-Bench-Verified benchmark, SWE-Compressor attains a 57.6% task-solved rate and clearly surpasses ReAct-style agents and static, heuristic-based compression baselines. It preserves reasoning quality while keeping interactions within a limited context budget, showing better stability and scalability for long-horizon SWE tasks.
AI.conclusion: Elevating context management to a first-class, learnable tool within LLM agents enables more robust long-horizon reasoning on large codebases. The CAT paradigm and the trained SWE-Compressor demonstrate that proactive, structured compression of interaction histories outperforms passive or static strategies, suggesting a promising direction for building scalable, repository-level SWE agents under bounded context windows.

title: Introducing TrGLUE and SentiTurca: A Comprehensive Benchmark for Turkish General Language Understanding and Sentiment Analysis
summary: Evaluating the performance of various model architectures, such as transformers, large language models (LLMs), and other NLP systems, requires comprehensive benchmarks that measure performance across multiple dimensions. Among these, the evaluation of natural language understanding (NLU) is particularly critical as it serves as a fundamental criterion for assessing model capabilities. Thus, it is essential to establish benchmarks that enable thorough evaluation and analysis of NLU abilities from diverse perspectives. While the GLUE benchmark has set a standard for evaluating English NLU, similar benchmarks have been developed for other languages, such as CLUE for Chinese, FLUE for French, and JGLUE for Japanese. However, no comparable benchmark currently exists for the Turkish language. To address this gap, we introduce TrGLUE, a comprehensive benchmark encompassing a variety of NLU tasks for Turkish. In addition, we present SentiTurca, a specialized benchmark for sentiment analysis. To support researchers, we also provide fine-tuning and evaluation code for transformer-based models, facilitating the effective use of these benchmarks. TrGLUE comprises Turkish-native corpora curated to mirror the domains and task formulations of GLUE-style evaluations, with labels obtained through a semi-automated pipeline that combines strong LLM-based annotation, cross-model agreement checks, and subsequent human validation. This design prioritizes linguistic naturalness, minimizes direct translation artifacts, and yields a scalable, reproducible workflow. With TrGLUE, our goal is to establish a robust evaluation framework for Turkish NLU, empower researchers with valuable resources, and provide insights into generating high-quality semi-automated datasets.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces TrGLUE, the first GLUE-style Turkish NLU benchmark, plus a sentiment benchmark SentiTurca, built with semi-automated LLM-based labeling and human validation.
AI.motivation: There is no comprehensive, standardized benchmark to evaluate natural language understanding (NLU) performance of models for the Turkish language, unlike English (GLUE) and other major languages (CLUE, FLUE, JGLUE). This gap hinders rigorous, comparable assessment and development of Turkish NLP models.
AI.method: The authors construct TrGLUE, a suite of Turkish-native NLU corpora aligned with GLUE-style domains and task formats. They design a semi-automated labeling pipeline that uses strong LLM-based annotation, cross-model agreement checks, and human validation to obtain high-quality labels while maintaining linguistic naturalness and minimizing translation artifacts. They also build SentiTurca, a focused sentiment analysis benchmark, and release fine-tuning and evaluation code for transformer-based models.
AI.result: The outcome is a comprehensive Turkish NLU benchmark (TrGLUE) covering multiple tasks, a dedicated sentiment benchmark (SentiTurca), and accompanying code resources that enable standardized evaluation and fine-tuning of transformer models for Turkish. The datasets are scalable, reproducible, and better reflect natural Turkish usage rather than translated text, though specific quantitative results are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: TrGLUE and SentiTurca fill the missing standardized evaluation framework for Turkish NLU, provide practical tools and resources for researchers, and demonstrate that semi-automated, LLM-assisted labeling pipelines—augmented with cross-model checks and human validation—can create high-quality, linguistically natural benchmarks at scale.
